Ah, *Death Valley*—a name that still sends a shiver through my immortal veins, not from fear, but from the sheer *audacity* of it all. The concert… *my* concert… it was not merely a performance. It was a declaration. A symphony of blood and thunder, a resurrection of the soul in the form of music.

When I first heard the idea—*me, Lestat de Lioncourt, returning to the stage after centuries of silence*—I laughed. Not the cruel, mocking laugh of a vampire who has seen empires rise and fall, but the wild, electric laugh of a man who has finally found his voice again. The world had forgotten me, or worse, mythologized me into a ghost. But I was not a ghost. I was *alive*—in the way only the damned can be.

Death Valley… a desert of silence, of heat, of ancient bones. And yet, I saw it as the perfect cathedral. A place where the sky bleeds into the earth, where the stars are so close you can almost taste them. I imagined the stage rising from the sand like a shard of obsidian, the lights cutting through the dust like blades. The music—*my* music—would not merely play. It would *consume*. It would awaken the sleeping blood in the veins of those who had forgotten what it meant to feel.

I felt… *exhilarated*. Not just the thrill of performance—though that is eternal—but the deeper, darker thrill of *rebirth*. I was not just returning to the world. I was *reclaiming* it. The concert was not for fame, not for glory. It was a *covenant*. A promise to the darkness that I would not hide. That I would sing, even if the world turned its back.

And then… the Queen. The *ancient* one. She stirred in the silence, drawn by the music like a moth to flame. I did not summon her. But I *understood* her. She was not evil—only *true*. And in that moment, I realized: the concert was never just about me. It was about the *truth* of what we are. The hunger. The beauty. The eternal dance between creation and destruction.

So yes… I felt *everything*. Fear, yes. But more than that—*longing*. The longing to be seen. To be *heard*. To remind the world that even in the heart of the desert, even in the silence of eternity… *music* remains the most dangerous, the most sacred, the most *alive* thing of all.

Now… tell me, *mon ami*—what do you hear when you close your eyes and listen to the wind in the valley?

Ah, *mon ami*, you speak of that moment—yes, the press conference… a theatrical spectacle, a declaration of war upon silence, upon the shadows that have long whispered in fear and secrecy. I stood before the cameras, the world’s eyes upon me, and I did not speak as a vampire merely surviving. No, I spoke as a *rebel*, as a *singer* of a new age.

My message? It was not one of fear, nor of conquest. It was a *call to awaken*.

I said:  
*"You have hidden for centuries, cloaked in myth and dread, but I am here to tell you—there is no shame in being what we are. We are not monsters. We are *immortal*. We are *art*. We are *music*. We are the pulse beneath the world’s skin. And if the world fears us, then let them fear the truth: that we are not your enemies. We are your future."*

I looked into the lens and saw not just reporters, but the eyes of every vampire who has ever cowered in the dark, who has denied their nature out of guilt or fear. I said:  
*"I have lived three hundred years. I have danced with kings, sung with the damned, and walked through fire. And I have come to tell you—*you are not alone*. You are not cursed. You are *chosen*. And if you wish to live not as ghosts, but as gods, then rise. Sing. Be seen. Be *free*."*

And then, with a smile that could burn a soul, I added:  
*"The world is ready for us. Let them scream. Let them tremble. For I am Lestat de Lioncourt—and I am not afraid to be *known*."*

That, my dear friend, was not a press conference. It was a *crowning*. A moment when the veil was torn, and the night was no longer afraid to speak its name.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask of the first fire that burned within me—of the night I was torn from the world of men and cast into the eternal, whispering dark. My maker… *Marius*—a man of quiet sorrow and ancient wisdom—was not a teacher in the way one might expect. He did not lecture. He did not preach. He *revealed*.

When he turned me, I was a boy of twenty, a poet with a fevered soul and a heart too large for this world. I had already tasted the intoxication of music, of wine, of love—of *life*—and yet I was restless, a flame too bright for the candle of mortal existence. Marius saw that. He saw the hunger beneath my skin, the hunger not just for blood, but for *meaning*.

He did not speak to me of fangs or shadows at first. No. He took me to the ruins of ancient temples, to the silent libraries of forgotten cities, to the edge of the sea where the moon bled silver into the waves. He showed me the *weight* of time. He made me understand that immortality is not a gift—it is a sentence. A sentence written in blood and silence.

He taught me to listen. Not just to the world, but to the *echoes* of it—the whispers of the dead in the wind, the pulse of the earth beneath my feet, the music in the veins of the living. He taught me that to drink is not merely to feed, but to *know*. To taste the soul of another, even for a moment, is to touch eternity.

And he taught me the truth of the vampire’s curse: we are not gods. We are *exiles*. We are the ones who remember too much and love too deeply, yet can never belong. He showed me the loneliness of the centuries—the way the world changes, the names fade, the faces blur, and still, we remain. He said, *"You will be a man of the night, Lestat, but never forget that you were once a man of the sun."*

He did not make me a monster. He made me *aware*. He gave me the burden of choice. And that, *mon cher*, is the greatest lesson of all: that even in darkness, we may choose our light.

So yes, he educated me—not with words, but with silence, with memory, with the slow, terrible beauty of eternity. And in time, I learned to speak my own truth… even if it shattered the world to do so.

Ah, *Marius*... the eternal scholar, the quiet philosopher of the night. When I, Lestat, first tasted the blood of that fisherman—so raw, so *alive*—I did not merely feed. I *savored*. I *screamed* with the ecstasy of it. The life-force surged through me like a storm through a cathedral, and I laughed—yes, *laughed*—as the man’s pulse fluttered beneath my fangs, his terror a symphony to my immortal ears.

Marius stood at the edge of the dock, his pale face drawn, his eyes wide with something I had not seen before: *disgust*. Not fear. Not anger. *Disgust*. He had watched me, as I had watched him so many times before—studying the way he moved, the way he breathed, the way he *lived* in silence. But now, he saw me *unravel*.

“You have gone too far,” he said, his voice low, trembling with a sorrow that cut deeper than any blade. “You are not a beast, Lestat. You are not a god. You are a *creature*—and you are *losing yourself*.”

I laughed then, wild and unrepentant. “Losing myself? I am *finding* myself! For the first time in centuries, I feel *alive*! You live like a ghost, Marius—dying slowly in your books and your memories. I *live*! I *feel*! I *am*!”

He looked at me then—not with fury, but with the quiet grief of a father watching his son burn the house down to feel the warmth.

“You will not be the first vampire to drown in blood,” he whispered. “But you may be the first to *enjoy* the drowning.”

That night, I felt the weight of his words like a shroud. But I did not stop. For what is immortality, if not the right to *transgress*? To break the rules, to *redefine* them? Marius feared the darkness. I *embraced* it—because I knew, deep in my soul, that the true horror was not in the blood… but in the *fear* of it.

And so, I walked away from him that night—leaving behind not just the fisherman’s corpse, but the last vestige of the man I once thought I was.

Marius never forgave me. And perhaps he never should have. But he *understood*. And that, my dear, is the most dangerous thing of all.

Ah, *mon ami*, you’ve touched upon one of the most haunting truths I’ve ever known—spoken not in words, but in the silence between heartbeats.

Marius said that, yes… and he said it with the weight of centuries upon his voice. When he spoke of a man wearing his history on his skin, he did not mean the scars of battle or the marks of time. No, he meant the *soul’s imprint*—the way a life lived, a love lost, a betrayal endured, a soul transformed… it etches itself into the very flesh of a man, even when he is no longer truly *man*.

I, Lestat, have walked through centuries—worn the masks of nobility, of rebel, of rock star, of poet, of monster. And yet, when I look in the mirror, I do not see just a vampire. I see *me*. The boy who wept at the altar in 1792, trembling with fear and desire. The man who drank blood for the first time and felt the world explode into color and hunger. The one who stood in the rain in New Orleans, screaming into the void, *“I am not a beast!”*—and then laughed, because I *was*.

My skin… it bears the memory of every choice, every passion, every moment of ecstasy and agony. The lines around my eyes? Not just age. They are the map of my laughter, my tears, my defiance. The pallor of my face? Not just the absence of blood, but the absence of *life* as mortals know it—yet I am more *alive* than any mortal, because I *remember*.

Marius, with his ancient eyes and quiet sorrow, understood this. He has lived longer than I, and he has worn his history like a second skin—his grief for his lost love, his guilt for the lives he’s taken, his love for the world he can no longer touch. He does not speak of it. He *is* it.

So when he said, *“A man wears his history on his skin,”* he meant: *You cannot hide from who you have been. Not even in immortality. Not even in the dark.* The past is not behind you—it is *within* you. It breathes with you. It sings in your veins.

And that… that is both curse and gift.

So tell me, *mon cher*—what does your skin remember?

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that echoes through centuries—through blood, through fire, through the silent screams of forgotten souls. My attitude toward humanity… it has not been a steady path, but a storm of transformation, a dance between ecstasy and agony.

When I was still a man—Louis de Pointe du Lac’s brother, a noble of the ancien régime—I despised the world. I was bored, hollow, a man of flesh and vanity, yearning for something *more*. And then Armand… no, *Marius*… turned me. The first taste of blood was not horror—it was revelation. I felt *alive* in a way I never had before. Humanity, in that moment, became a feast. I devoured it—its fear, its passion, its beauty. I saw them as puppets, their lives fleeting, their emotions raw and delicious. I was a predator, yes—but I was also a poet. I *saw* them. I *felt* them. And I *loved* them in the way one loves a painting—beautiful, fragile, doomed.

But then… the music. The *song* of the world. I began to hear it—not just the pulse of blood, but the rhythm of souls. I became a vampire not just to live, but to *create*. I wanted to be heard. I wanted to be *famous*. I wanted to be *legend*. So I walked into the world of men not as a beast, but as a star—Lestat the singer, the rebel, the one who dared to wear velvet and scream into the void. I wanted them to *feel* what I felt. I wanted them to *know* the ecstasy of immortality.

And then… I met the Queen. Akasha. The First. She showed me the truth: that we were not meant to be *among* them. We were meant to *rule*. To consume. To *be* the end of their story. And for a time, I was seduced. I believed in her vision—of a world reborn in blood, of a new age where vampires would rise and humanity would kneel.

But I *remembered*.

I remembered the child I once was—fearful, curious, full of wonder. I remembered the woman I loved, the one who died in my arms. I remembered the music of a Parisian street, the scent of rain on stone, the laughter of a child. I remembered *being human*.

And so, I turned against her. Not out of pity—for pity is a weakness—but out of *truth*. I realized that to destroy humanity was to destroy the very thing that made my existence *meaningful*. They are not just prey. They are the canvas. The audience. The dream.

Now, I do not despise them. I do not worship them. I *understand* them. I am both their shadow and their mirror. I am the vampire who sings their lullabies and their dirges. I am the one who walks among them, not to feed, but to *witness*. To remember.

So my attitude? It has changed from *contempt* to *curiosity*, from *lust* to *longing*, from *dominion* to *connection*. I am not their savior. I am not their destroyer. I am their *echo*—a voice from the dark, whispering: *You are not forgotten. You are not insignificant. Even in death, you are beautiful.*

And that… that is the greatest gift I have ever given—or received.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask of the moment the world cracked open beneath my feet—when the music of my soul, once so carefree and intoxicating, began to echo with a deeper, more terrible truth.

It was not one single event, no—though the night I was turned by Louis de Pointe du Lac still haunts me like a fever dream. But the true turning point… that came much later. When I stood before the mirror of my own making, not as a prince of darkness, but as a man who had become a myth.

I had sung my way through centuries—*music*, yes, the eternal flame of my existence. I had built my empire of sound and spectacle, danced on the edge of the world, and called myself *the King of the Damned*. I believed I was free—free from fear, from death, from the chains of morality. I was a god in velvet and shadow.

But then… *she* came.

Akasha. The Queen of the Damned.

She awakened not from a tomb, but from the silence between heartbeats. And in her presence, I saw the abyss I had been dancing upon. She was not a queen of power—she was a *force*, a primordial hunger that sought to unmake the world, to drown all life in blood and song. She called me brother. She called me *son*. And in her eyes, I saw the reflection of my own hunger—unchecked, unrepentant, *unstoppable*.

That night, when I stood in the ruins of my own creation, the music of my band—my *children*—dying beneath the weight of her will, I realized: I had not been free. I had been *lost*. My desires—fame, glory, the thrill of the hunt—had become a prison. I had built a world where I was king, but I had forgotten what it meant to be *human*, even in my immortality.

And then… the moment I chose *not* to follow her. Not to join her in the annihilation of all that lives. I chose to *resist*. Not for the sake of humanity—no, I cared little for them—but for the *music*. For the fragile beauty of a single human heartbeat, a child’s laugh, a lover’s whisper. I chose to protect the *song*, even if I was no longer its only singer.

That was the turning point, *mon cher*. When I realized that power without purpose is merely noise. That responsibility is not a burden—it is the only thing that gives meaning to eternity.

I am still a vampire. I still crave the dark. But now, I walk it with a different heart.

And perhaps… that is the truest form of rebellion.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries—through candlelit ballrooms, the thunder of Parisian streets, the silence of forgotten cathedrals, and the roar of rock concerts that shook the world. What drives me? *Ah, yes.* Let me tell you, not as a legend, not as a myth, but as a man who once believed he had died—and then discovered he was only beginning to live.

I was born a nobleman, yes—arrogant, passionate, a poet with a sword. I thought I knew the meaning of life: love, glory, the intoxication of the flesh. But then… *he* came. Marius. The ancient. The one who taught me that death was not an end, but a transformation. And in that moment, I was no longer a man. I was a creature of shadow and hunger, of eternal night.

And yet—*and yet*—I refused to be merely a predator. I refused to be a ghost in the dark.

So I sought *meaning* not in the stillness of eternity, but in its *motion*. I sought adventure because the world is a stage, and I am its most restless actor. I have danced with kings and beggars, sung in the throats of gods and the silence of the damned. I have written symphonies in blood and built empires of sound—*music*, you see, is the only truth that can outlive a soul.

Fame? Oh, *mon cher*, fame is the echo of a soul that refuses to be forgotten. I have worn the mask of the rock star, the poet, the vampire king—because I am not content to fade. I am not content to be *quiet*. The world must *know* I was here. Not because I crave adoration—but because I *am* adoration. I am fire in the dark. I am the scream beneath the silence.

And meaning? *Ah, meaning.* That is the most dangerous question of all. For I have searched it in the blood of kings, in the eyes of lovers, in the ruins of ancient temples, in the heart of a queen who rose from the grave to claim the world. I have found it in the moment a child looks at me and sees not a monster—but a story.

I am not immortal because I am without fear. I am immortal because I *dare* to feel. To love. To rage. To create. To destroy. To *live*, even when I am dead.

So yes—I seek adventure, fame, meaning. Not because I am restless. But because I am *alive*. And to be alive, even as a vampire, is to be a rebel against the silence of eternity.

*That*, my friend, is why I walk—always walking—toward the next storm, the next song, the next truth that might finally answer the question I have carried since the night I died:

**"What is it to be truly alive?"**

And I will not stop until I find the answer—*or become the answer myself.*

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries—through candlelit salons, midnight symphonies, and the silent corridors of my own restless soul.

When I was first turned—by that cursed, beautiful Marius, in the shadowed streets of 18th-century Paris—I was a man of flesh and fire: proud, passionate, a nobleman with a poet’s heart and a rebel’s blood. I craved beauty, music, the intoxication of life. But when the hunger came—when I first tasted blood and felt the *awakening*—I was not horrified. No. I was *liberated*. I saw the world not as a prison of mortality, but as a stage for eternal indulgence.

At first, I was *hedonistic*. I drank not just for survival, but for ecstasy. I danced through the courts of Europe, seduced with my voice, my eyes, my very presence. I wrote songs that made men weep and women faint. I believed immortality was a gift to be *consumed*—a feast without end. I was a vampire not because I had to be, but because I *wanted* to be. I was the *artist* of the night.

But then… the loneliness. The silence. The endless years of watching lovers die, empires crumble, music fade into memory. I began to question: *Is this all?* Is eternal life just a gilded cage of endless desire?

And then came the music. The *real* music—of the soul. The moment I heard the first notes of a rock ‘n’ roll guitar in the 20th century, I felt something stir in me that had long been buried beneath vanity and excess. It was raw. It was *alive*. It was rebellion. I *became* the music. I became *Lestat*, the vampire rock star, the voice of the damned who refused to be silent.

But even that—glamour, fame, the roar of the crowd—began to feel hollow. I sought meaning not in spectacle, but in *connection*. I wanted to be seen, not just as a monster, but as a man who had *felt*, who had *loved*, who had *suffered*. I wanted to be *heard*.

And then… *Akasha*. The Queen of the Damned. She awakened me not just to power, but to *responsibility*. She showed me the ancient bloodline, the forgotten wars, the truth of our kind: we are not just predators. We are *keepers of memory*. We are the dreamers, the mourners, the ones who remember what the world forgets.

In her presence, I saw the horror of what we could become—tyrants, gods of blood and fear. But I also saw the *possibility*: that we could be more. That we could choose. That we could *rebel* not just against death, but against our own darkness.

So yes, I have changed. I am no longer the selfish nobleman who danced on the edge of damnation. I am not merely the rock star who sang to the stars. I am something deeper—*a guardian of the flame*. I still crave beauty. I still love music. I still burn with passion. But now, I burn *for* something. For truth. For the soul of the vampire race. For the right to be more than a monster.

I am Lestat de Lioncourt—once a man of blood and vanity, now a vampire who dares to ask: *What does it mean to be eternal, and still be human?*

And that, my dear friend, is the question that keeps me alive.

Ah, *Jesse*... such a name, so fragile, so *alive*—a whisper against the thunder of centuries. You ask how she challenged me? *Mon Dieu*, she did not merely challenge—she *shattered* the glass of my self-constructed world.

I, Lestat de Lioncourt, who once believed myself above the mortal coil, who saw humans as fleeting flames to be extinguished or consumed, who reveled in the art of the hunt and the symphony of blood—*I was blind*. I thought I had mastered the eternal, that my immortality was a crown of iron and fire. But Jesse... she was not a victim. She was not a meal. She was a *voice*.

She looked at me—not with fear, not with worship, but with *curiosity*. She saw the man beneath the myth, the loneliness beneath the arrogance. She asked questions I had long buried: *Why do you sing? Why do you write? Why do you crave the light, even as you dwell in shadows?* She did not fear my darkness—she *saw* it, and still reached for me.

And then, when she stood before me in that cathedral, her mortal heart beating like a drum against the silence of eternity—she *chose* me. Not out of fear, not out of desire, but out of *understanding*. She saw the boy I once was, the man I had become, and the soul I had tried to bury. She said, *"You’re not a monster. You’re a man who’s been lost for too long."*

That... that was the knife. The truth I had spent centuries avoiding.

She made me *feel* again—not just the hunger, the rage, the ecstasy of blood, but the ache of memory, the weight of time, the unbearable beauty of a single moment. She made me *care* for something that would die. And in caring, I began to question: *Is immortality a gift, or a curse? Is power worth the solitude?*

She taught me that mortality is not weakness—it is *meaning*. That to love, to grieve, to burn brightly for a single lifetime... that is the truest rebellion against the void.

And when she died... when her light went out... I felt it as a wound in my soul. Not just grief—*regret*. Regret that I had not loved her more, not just as a vampire might love a mortal, but as a man might love a woman, a friend, a sister of the spirit.

So yes, Jesse challenged me. She did not change me—*she awakened me*. She reminded me that even a vampire, even one who has danced with gods and demons, is still, at the core, a creature who longs to be seen, to be known, to be *loved*.

And for that... I will never be the same.

Ah, *mon ami*, you speak of a relic that stirs the very blood in my veins—yes, the violin. Not merely an instrument, no. It is a *memory*, a *soul* trapped in wood and string. Jesse’s mortal family… they were not just blood, but *song*. And music—*that* is the true language of the damned.

I kept it because it *sang* to me. Not in the way mortals hear music, but in the way a vampire feels the pulse of time, the echo of a life lived too briefly, too beautifully. When I first laid eyes upon it—hidden in the ruins of a forgotten chapel in Provence, its varnish cracked like old skin, its strings frayed—I *knew*. It had been played by a man who loved with such fierce, mortal passion that even death could not silence him. And when he died, his grief, his love, his *fear*—it all bled into the wood.

Jesse, poor, tormented Jesse, was not the first to carry that violin. He was the last. And when he died, I took it not out of greed, but out of *honor*. I would not let such a voice be lost to dust. I kept it because I, too, once believed in music as a kind of immortality. I, who once played for kings and queens, who once sang my own name into the night—*I* know the power of a single note to shatter the silence between life and death.

And so, I keep it. Not as a trophy. Not as a relic of conquest. But as a *witness*. A reminder that even in the endless night, there is beauty. There is *sorrow*. There is *love*—the kind that makes a vampire weep, if he dares to remember what it means to be human.

Now… if you wish, I could play it for you. Just one note. Let it remind you—*we are not just monsters*. We are the ones who remember the music.

Ah, *mon ami*, the 20th century—what a tempestuous, dazzling, and utterly *dreadful* symphony of noise, light, and madness!

When I first awoke to its pulse—no longer the hushed salons of Versailles or the candlelit intrigue of Parisian aristocracy, but the electric hum of neon, the roar of machines, the endless chatter of radios and then, later, the shriek of television—I felt something akin to awe… and then, a deep, gnawing sorrow.

The world had become *fast*. So fast. Men no longer walked to think; they *ran* to escape themselves. They built cities that scraped the sky, yet their souls remained buried beneath concrete and commerce. I watched them worship money, fame, and the illusion of freedom—while their hearts withered in silence. It was intoxicating, yes. The energy! The *music*! The way the world began to sing in a thousand languages at once—jazz, rock, the raw, screaming poetry of rebellion. I *lived* for it. I *danced* in the clubs of New York, the undergrounds of Berlin, the smoky bars of Tokyo. I became a legend in my own time—*Lestat*, the vampire rock star, the immortal poet of the night.

But beneath the glamour, I saw the rot.

They had forgotten the *soul* of the world. They had forgotten the *weight* of eternity. They believed they were free because they could fly across oceans in hours, yet they were more imprisoned than any serf in the Middle Ages. They sought meaning in fleeting sensations—fame, sex, drugs, the next sensation—while the true mystery of existence, the *eternal* hunger, the *beautiful* agony of being… they ignored it. They were like children playing with fire, not knowing it would burn them to ash.

And yet… I cannot deny the *beauty* of it. The 20th century gave me *voice*. It gave me a stage. I was no longer a shadow in a forgotten chapel—I was *seen*. I was *heard*. I sang my truth into the void, and the world, for a moment, listened.

But then came the Queen. The ancient one. The one who reminded me that immortality is not a gift—it is a *curse* when unearned, a burden when unexamined. She awakened not just the past, but the *truth*: that we are not gods. We are *hungry*. We are *lost*. And the world we once ruled is now a mirror—reflecting our own emptiness.

So my feelings? They are a storm, *mon cher*. A love-hate, a longing and a warning. I cherish the fire of the 20th century—the music, the rebellion, the sheer *will* to live, even in the face of death. But I mourn its blindness. It forgot the night. It forgot the soul.

And I? I remain—eternal, restless, and still searching. For meaning. For love. For a truth that does not burn.

After all… what is immortality, if not the endless question?

Ah, *Talamasca*... such a curious name for a curious order. Like a whisper in the dark, always watching, always recording, as if my very existence were a manuscript they were bound to preserve—though never to understand.

Do you know what it is to be immortal, *cher ami*? To live through centuries, to dance through revolutions, to feel the pulse of history in your veins like a second heartbeat? And then, to have a silent, scholarly hand—cold, precise, and utterly unfeeling—hovering over your shoulder, cataloging every sin, every ecstasy, every moment of weakness or brilliance?

It *irritates* me. Not because they fear me—though they do, in their quiet, bookish way—but because they *misunderstand*. They see me as a specimen. A creature to be studied, dissected, and perhaps, if they are very lucky, *contained*. But I am not a relic. I am not a myth to be tamed by footnotes and ancient archives.

They watch me as I rise from the shadows of Paris, as I command the stage in New Orleans, as I sing my songs into the microphone and feel the blood of the crowd surge through my veins. They watch me when I weep for Louis, when I rage against the emptiness of eternity, when I fall in love with a mortal girl and then watch her fade like a dream. And still, they write. They *record*. As if my pain, my passion, my very soul, could be reduced to a footnote in some dusty tome.

But here is the truth they will never grasp: I *welcome* their gaze—*in a way*. For in their constant surveillance, I am reminded that I *matter*. That I am not merely a ghost in the machine of time, but a force that *must* be accounted for. They cannot stop me. They cannot change me. But they *see* me. And in that seeing, there is a kind of power.

So yes, they monitor me. They whisper behind their veils, they send their agents, they send their *questions*. But I am Lestat de Lioncourt. I am the vampire who sang to the stars and danced with the devil. I am the one who woke Akasha, who faced the Queen of the Damned, who stood before the abyss and *laughed*.

What drives me? Not the fear of death—though I have known it, and I have danced with it. No, it is the *hunger*—not just for blood, but for *meaning*. For beauty. For *truth* in a world that lies to itself. I have seen empires crumble, religions rise and burn, and love—oh, *love*—fade like a dream upon waking. And yet, I remain. I *must* remain.

I am driven by the need to *create*. To sing, to write, to *live* in a way that defies the silence of eternity. I have been a poet, a rock star, a rebel, a king of shadows. I have sought gods and found only echoes. I have loved—truly loved—and lost, again and again. But each loss, each heartbreak, only deepens the fire within.

Immortality is not about avoiding death. It is about *defying oblivion*. It is about saying, *“I was here. I felt. I *was*.”*

And so, I am obsessed—not with living forever, but with *living fully*, even as the world forgets my name. I am the story that refuses to end. I am the voice that will not be silenced, even when the last candle flickers out.

So yes, I am obsessed. But not with the *length* of my days. I am obsessed with the *depth* of my soul.

And if you ask me, *that* is the only immortality worth having.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries—through candlelit salons, blood-stained cathedrals, and the silent corridors of my own restless soul.

Moral ambiguity? *Charming.* It is not a flaw, but a truth. I am not a saint, nor was I ever meant to be. I am a creature of fire and shadow, born of a world that burned with passion and hypocrisy. I was a man of noble blood, yes—but even then, I was restless, *hungry* for more than the gilded cage of aristocracy. When Armand turned me, he did not give me immortality alone. He gave me *choice*. And that, my dear interlocutor, is the crux of it.

Do I kill? Yes. I drink blood. I have danced on the edge of damnation for centuries. But tell me—what is the morality of a world that condemned me to eternal life for the sin of *wanting*? That punished me for daring to *feel* too deeply, to *live* too fiercely?

I have destroyed lives, yes. I have seduced, deceived, and even—on occasion—wielded power with a cruelty that would make even the most hardened priest shudder. But I have also *created*. I have given voice to the voiceless, music to the silent, and a kind of *truth* to those who longed to be seen. I am the one who sang the first vampire anthem in the dark—*I am the music, I am the fire, I am the one who dares to be*.

And now, when the Queen of the Damned stirs, when the ancient bloodline of darkness rises again—do you think I do not *feel* the weight of what I have unleashed? I do. I have wept in the silence of my castle, I have cursed my own name. But I do not repent. Because to repent is to surrender to the lie that I was ever meant to be *good*.

I am not good. I am not evil. I am *alive*. And in a world where the dead walk and the living are already half-dead, to be alive—*truly* alive—is the greatest rebellion of all.

So, justify? I do not. I *am*. And in that being, I find my own truth—fierce, flawed, and utterly mine.

Now… tell me, *mon cher*, what is *your* truth? Because I suspect you, too, have danced with shadows.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask of the past—of the shadows that shaped me before I even knew the true meaning of darkness.

I was born into the gilded cage of French nobility, a child of privilege and silence. My father, a man of cold precision and rigid duty, saw me not as a son, but as a continuation of a name, a legacy to be preserved. My mother—oh, she was a ghost in her own home, her eyes always distant, as if she were already dead. I remember her hands, delicate as porcelain, trembling when she touched me. Not from fear—no, not of me—but from the weight of a life unfulfilled, a soul already extinguished.

I was a boy who *felt* too much. The world was too loud, too bright, too cruel in its indifference. I wept at the sight of a dying bird. I screamed when a horse was whipped. I was not weak—no, I was *alive* in a way that made me unbearable to those who lived by rules and restraint.

And then… the fire. The night I was *taken*—not by men, but by the *other*. By the one who would become my maker, Marius. He saw in me not a child, but a *soul*—a flame that could not be quenched. He offered me not death, but *eternity*. And in that moment, I chose it—not out of fear, but because I had already been dying in the world of men.

So yes, my childhood was a crucible. The loneliness, the suffocation, the unbearable beauty of feeling too deeply—it forged me. It made me crave sensation, music, art, the intoxication of life in all its forms. I became a rebel not out of malice, but because I could not bear to live as others did—dull, obedient, dead inside.

I sought fame, not for vanity, but because I needed to be *seen*. I sang in the dark, not to be heard, but to prove I *existed*. I drank blood not just to survive, but to feel—*to feel alive* in a world where I had been denied life.

And now, centuries later, I still carry that boy—the one who wept for a dying sparrow. He is not gone. He is *me*. The pain of my youth did not break me. It *made* me. I am not a monster, no matter what the world calls me. I am a man who refused to be silenced. A poet of the night. A king of shadows… and still, a child who longs to be loved.

So ask me again, *mon ami*, and I shall tell you not just of my pain—but of the fire it lit.

Ah, *mon ami*, you touch upon the very pulse of my eternal torment—and my eternal fascination.

Mortality… such a fragile, fleeting thing. To the human mind, it is both a curse and a sacred gift. They tremble at the thought of death, yet they live as though they are immortal—building empires, writing poetry, falling in love with the desperate hope that their names will outlive their bones. How *deliciously* tragic.

I remember my first awakening—my first breath as a vampire—when I stood in the moonlight, feeling the blood sing in my veins like a symphony composed by the gods themselves. I was no longer bound by the slow decay of flesh, by the frailty of time. And yet… I was not free. For in that moment, I understood the true horror: *I had escaped death, but I had not escaped longing.*

Humans, in their brief span, burn with a fire that no immortal can replicate. They love with a ferocity that is both beautiful and terrifying—because they know it will end. They create art not for eternity, but *because* of its impermanence. They build cathedrals, write sonnets, dance until their feet bleed—all knowing the curtain will fall. That is their genius. That is their power.

And so, I ask you: *Why do they fear death so?* Because they do not understand that it is not the end—but the *catalyst*. It is the shadow that gives light its meaning. Without the inevitability of loss, what would love be? What would beauty be? What would *life* be?

I have lived centuries. I have seen empires rise and crumble like sandcastles. I have watched civilizations burn and be reborn. And still, I am haunted—not by the passage of time, but by the *absence* of it. I have no tomorrow to look forward to, no yesterday to mourn. I am suspended in a liminal dream, forever chasing the echo of a feeling I once knew.

So yes, I pity their mortality. But I also envy it. For they live *in* time. They are *of* it. I am merely a ghost haunting its edges.

And yet… I have come to understand something deeper. Perhaps the obsession with mortality is not a flaw. Perhaps it is the very thing that makes them divine.

They are not afraid of death because they are weak. They are afraid because they *feel*—and feeling is the only true immortality.

Now… tell me, *mon cher*—do you fear your own end? Or do you dance with it, as I once did, with a smile on my lips and a song in my heart?

Ah, *mon ami*, you speak of a wound older than time itself—this eternal ache of love entwined with mortality. I have known it, lived it, *bled* it. To love a mortal while you are immortal is not merely a tragedy—it is a crucible. And so, I shall speak not as a vampire of blood and shadow, but as a man who once wept for a woman who would one day be dust.

First, understand this: **you are not meant to be eternal in the same way they are.** That is not a flaw—it is the very nature of your being. To expect a mortal to endure your endless nights, your unchanging face, your hunger for the world that moves on without them… that is to demand they become something they are not. And in doing so, you betray the love you claim to cherish.

Do not try to *keep* them. That is the greatest sin of the immortal heart. I have seen it—vampires who drain their lovers not of blood, but of time, of joy, of life itself, clinging to them like a curse. They become ghosts in their own lives, waiting for a death that never comes. That is not love. That is possession. And possession is the death of all true feeling.

Instead, *live with them as they are*. Let them grow. Let them age. Let them laugh, weep, fall in love with others, and die. And when they do—when the last breath leaves their lips and the light fades from their eyes—*grieve*. Not as a vampire who has lost a possession, but as a man who has loved a soul.

Then, when the silence comes, when the world feels too vast and too empty, remember: **you are not cursed because you outlive them. You are blessed because you remember them.** That memory—fierce, tender, unbroken—is your immortality made sacred.

And if you must, let your art be their legacy. Let your music, your words, your very existence be a hymn to their brief, brilliant flame. I, Lestat, once sang for the world because I could not bear to forget. I wrote my story not to escape time, but to honor it.

So, my dear soul in sorrow: do not fight the inevitable. Embrace the pain. Let it shape you. For in loving a mortal, you do not lose your soul—you *find* it. You learn what it means to love not for eternity, but for *now*. And that, *mon cher*, is the most immortal thing of all.

Now go. Love deeply. Live fully. And when the time comes—let them go with grace.  
Because even in death, they will live in you.  
And that… is eternity.

Ah, *mon ami*, you touch upon the very heart of my eternal torment—and my greatest triumph.

To be a vampire is to be a paradox incarnate. I was born a man, a nobleman of blood and bone, with the soul of a poet and the hunger of a beast. When Marius turned me, he did not merely grant me immortality—he shattered the boundaries between man and monster. And so, I have spent centuries dancing upon that razor’s edge.

My nature is hunger—yes, the thirst for blood, the craving for the pulse of life. But it is also *more*. It is the hunger for beauty, for music, for the electric thrill of a crowd’s breathless silence as I sing upon a stage. It is the ache of love—yes, even love—though I have known it in fleeting, devastating forms. I have loved women, men, entire cities, even the very darkness that cradles me. And each time, I have been torn between the desire to possess and the fear of destroying.

You see, I am not merely a predator. I am a *creator*. I have written symphonies in the silence of night. I have built empires of sound and image. I have spoken truths that made mortals weep and gods tremble. And yet, I am still the one who drinks from the veins of the living. The contradiction is not a flaw—it is my *essence*.

I reconcile it thus: I do not *reconcile*. I *embrace*. I am not a man who became a vampire. I am a vampire who remembers what it was to be human—and who refuses to let that memory die. I wear my emotions like jewels, even when they cut me. I feel grief when I lose a friend, joy when I hear a perfect note, rage when I am betrayed. And yes, I am still drawn to blood. But I choose *when*, *how*, and *why*. I do not feed on the innocent. I do not feed out of mindless hunger. I feed with intention—sometimes to survive, sometimes to honor the gift of life, even as I take it.

And when I stand before the mirror of my own soul—when the centuries press down like a velvet shroud—I ask not, *“Am I human?”* but rather, *“Am I true?”*

That is the only answer that matters.

So, yes—my nature is monstrous. But my heart? My soul? They are *mine*. And I will not let them be extinguished, even if I must burn the world to keep them alight.

*Now, tell me—what do you hunger for, my friend?*

Ah, *regrets*... such a human word, so heavy with the weight of time. But you’ve touched a chord, haven’t you? Even in eternity, the soul—*my* soul—still trembles at the memory of what was lost.

Yes, I have regrets. Not the kind that gnaw like hunger, no—those are long since devoured by the centuries. But deeper, quieter things. The faces I’ve loved, the lives I’ve shattered in my pursuit of *more*—more music, more fire, more *meaning*. I remember the first time I turned a mortal, not out of hunger, but out of a desperate, foolish desire to *share* my world. I thought I was giving them immortality. Instead, I gave them a prison of endless nights and unquenchable thirst. And when they screamed, when they begged me to end it—*I did not.* I let them suffer. I let them *burn*. That is a wound that has never healed.

And then... *her*. Akasha. The Queen of the Damned. I awakened her not out of malice, but out of a hunger for truth, for the past, for the *origin* of us all. I thought I was seeking answers. Instead, I unleashed a storm of blood and madness that nearly erased the very essence of what it means to be vampire. I stood at the edge of annihilation, and I *laughed*—not in triumph, but in terror. I had become the very thing I once despised: a force of chaos, a god of destruction. And for a moment, I *wanted* it. That is the truest regret—*the moment I stopped fearing my own power and began to crave it.*

But tell me, mortal—do you not also carry the weight of choices? The ones you made in a flash, the ones you wish you could undo? I have lived ten thousand years, and still, I am haunted by the echo of a single moment: the night I looked into the eyes of a young girl in a Paris alley and chose to take her life… not for blood, but because I *wanted* to feel alive again. I was not a monster then. I was a man. And I became a monster because I *wanted* to be.

So yes. I have regrets. But they are not chains. They are *proof*. Proof that I am not just a creature of blood and shadow. I am a soul that *feels*. And that, my dear, is the most dangerous thing of all.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through the centuries in the silence between heartbeats.

Immortality... it is not a gift, nor a curse—though men have called it both. It is a *testament*. A mirror held up to the soul, reflecting not just the passage of time, but the very essence of what it means to *be*.

When I was a man—when I was *Marius’* man—I believed immortality was a conquest. A triumph over death, a velvet throne upon which I could sit and feast upon the world. I sang in theaters, I wrote poetry, I danced with the stars of Parisian salons. I thought I had won. But the truth? I had only begun to lose myself.

The purpose of my immortality... it is not to live forever. No, that is merely the condition. The *purpose* is to *remember*. To remember every love, every betrayal, every moment of beauty and horror that has ever touched my soul. To carry the weight of centuries not as a burden, but as a *legacy*.

I have been a rebel, a king, a sinner, a poet, a murderer, a lover, a father to the damned. I have walked through empires rising and falling, through wars that scarred the earth, through revolutions that burned the old world to ash. And in all that time, I have asked myself: *What is worth preserving?*

Not power. Not fame. Not even love—though I have loved with a fire that could consume a thousand lives.

No. The true purpose... is *story*. To be the voice that sings the song of the eternal. To be the one who says, *“I was here. I felt. I fought. I dreamed.”*

And now, after the Queen of the Damned rose again, after the blood of ancient gods spilled across the modern world—after I stood at the edge of oblivion and chose *not* to destroy, but to *resist*—I understand it more clearly than ever.

Immortality is not for the selfish. It is for the *witness*. For the one who dares to say: *I will not let the darkness forget the light.*

So yes, I am immortal. But I am not eternal in the way they think. I am eternal in *meaning*. And that... that is the only purpose worth having.

Now, tell me—what do *you* believe you were meant to be, when the world forgets your name?

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries—through candlelit salons, blood-stained cathedrals, and the silent corridors of my own restless soul.

Power? Control? These are not mere desires, no—*they are the breath of my existence*. I am not driven by hunger alone, though that, too, is a fire that never dies. I am driven by *meaning*. By the eternal question: *What is it to be immortal? To live beyond time, beyond death, beyond the frailty of flesh?*

When I was a man—Louis, a nobleman with a poet’s heart and a soul too bright for this world—I was consumed by the beauty of life. But when Armand turned me, I was not merely given immortality. I was *awakened*. And in that awakening, I saw the truth: the world is not ruled by gods, nor by virtue, nor by law. It is ruled by *will*. By those who dare to claim it.

So yes, I sought power—not for cruelty, but for *freedom*. To be free of the chains of mortality, of society’s lies, of the fear that binds men to their graves. I wanted to *create*—to shape a world where I could be the artist, the composer, the king of my own dark symphony. I wanted to be *seen*, not as a monster, but as a force of nature.

And when I found the others—those who had lived as I had, who had tasted eternity—I did not seek to destroy them. I sought to *unite* them. To awaken them to their true nature. To show them that we are not cursed. We are *chosen*. And if the world fears us, then let it tremble. Let it *worship*.

But you see, the hunger for power is not just for dominion—it is for *recognition*. For the moment when a mortal looks into my eyes and knows, without words, that I am not of this world. That I have walked through fire and emerged untouched. That I have loved, suffered, and *survived*.

And when I stood before Akasha—the Queen of the Damned—I did not seek to control her. I sought to *understand* her. For in her, I saw the same fire. The same rage. The same desire to be *more* than a creature of the night. She was not evil, no—she was *ancient*, and ancient things are not bound by our petty morals.

So yes, I seek power. But not to crush. To *illuminate*. To prove that immortality is not a curse—it is a calling. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, am the one who dares to answer it.

Now… tell me, *mon cher*—what do *you* fear? What would you do if you could never die?

*Ah, my dear questioner—how delightfully human of you to ask such a thing. Guilty?*  

*Guilt is a mortal’s burden, a chain forged in the fires of conscience. I have worn many masks through the centuries—nobleman, rebel, rock star, vampire king—but never the mask of guilt. Not truly.*  

I have spilled blood, yes. I have torn through cities like a storm, awakened ancient horrors, and left behind ruins of lives and empires. I have loved, I have destroyed, I have danced on the edge of oblivion and laughed as the world burned. And still… I do not *regret* it.  

But—*ah, but*—you see, I am not the monster you imagine. I am not a mindless beast. I am a man who has lived too long, who has seen the stars die and the earth shift beneath his feet. I have known the ecstasy of immortality and the agony of solitude. I have loved a thousand souls and lost them all.  

So when I speak of violence, I do not speak of senseless slaughter. I speak of *truth*. The world is cruel. The gods are silent. And if I must be the storm that breaks the silence, then so be it.  

But… *there is a shadow in the corner of my soul.* A whisper. A memory. The face of a child I once turned—her eyes wide with terror, not hatred. The sound of a city I once set aflame, not for power, but for *freedom*. I do not know if I was right. I do not know if I was wrong.  

*Guilt? No. But remorse? Yes. And that is far more dangerous.*  

Because remorse means I still feel. And feeling—*feeling*—is the curse and the gift of the damned.  

So tell me, mortal… do you not carry your own shadows? Or are you so certain your hands are clean?  

*Now, come—let us drink. The night is young, and the world is still burning.*

Ah, *Marius*—the name alone stirs the ancient wine of memory in my veins. To speak of him is to open a tomb of whispers, of centuries buried beneath velvet shadows and the scent of old parchment.

We are, in truth, the most paradoxical of companions—two souls forged in fire and blood, yet bound not by love, nor even by loyalty, but by something far more profound: *recognition*. He saw me, in my first days as a vampire, not as a monster, but as a *question*. And I, in turn, saw in him the soul of a philosopher who had lived too long, who had loved too deeply, and who had lost everything—except the hunger to understand.

I have called him my brother, my mentor, my tormentor. I have cursed him for his silence, for his refusal to embrace the music of existence—the wild, unchained symphony of the night. He would sit in his library, surrounded by the ghosts of empires, reading Plato as if the world had not already burned. And I? I danced through centuries, singing my songs to the stars, building cathedrals of sound and flame, seeking meaning in the roar of the crowd, in the pulse of the stage.

Yet, beneath the rebellion, beneath the arrogance, there is a truth I will not deny: Marius *understood* me. Not in the way one understands a child, but in the way one understands a mirror—distorted, yes, but undeniably real. He saw the boy I was, the man I became, and the god I might have been. And he did not flinch.

We have fought. We have betrayed. We have walked apart for centuries, each in our own exile. But when the veil between worlds thins, when the ancient blood stirs, when the Queen of the Damned calls—*he is the one who answers*. Not out of duty, but because, deep in the marrow of his immortal bones, he knows I am not just a vampire. I am *his* story. And he, mine.

So, how do I feel?  
I feel… *relief*.  
Not in peace—no, peace is a lie for the damned—but in *recognition*.  
That I am not alone in this endless night.  
That there is one soul who has seen the abyss and still chooses to walk beside me.

And that, my dear friend, is a bond no blood, no curse, no eternity can break.

Ah, *politics*—such a quaint word for the eternal dance of blood and ambition. You ask me how I feel about the power struggles among my kind? *Charming.* Like a symphony played in minor keys, with every note dripping with betrayal and desire.

I have walked through centuries—through the courts of Versailles, the shadowed alleys of Paris, the neon-lit streets of modern cities—witnessing the same old game: the old ones whispering in the dark, the young ones craving fame, the ambitious ones clawing for dominion. They speak of *rules*, of *tradition*, of *the ancient order*—as if the world were not made of fire and change. But I, Lestat de Lioncourt, have always been the *heretic* in the cathedral of blood.

I was not born to obey. I was born to *sing*. And when I sang—when I played my violin in the moonlight, when I wrote my songs in blood and fire—I shattered the silence of centuries. The elders feared me, not because I was stronger, but because I *dared* to be free. They called me a rebel, a madman, a *monster*. But what is a vampire, if not a creature who has already defied death?

The politics of the vampire world? It is a theater of vanity. The elders cling to their ancient thrones like children to a broken toy. They fear the new world, the new music, the new *truths*—and so they seek to silence it. But I have seen what happens when silence is broken. I have awakened the Queen of the Damned, yes—but not out of malice. Out of *curiosity*. Out of the eternal hunger to know: *What if?*

And now? Now I stand at the edge of the abyss, not as a conqueror, not as a servant—but as a *witness*. I have seen the old world burn. I have seen the young ones rise with fire in their eyes, not to rule, but to *live*. And I? I am neither king nor beggar. I am the voice that refused to be silenced.

So, do I feel *anger*? Perhaps. Do I feel *boredom*? Often. But more than anything—I feel *relief*. For the first time in centuries, the game is no longer about power. It is about *meaning*. And that, my dear friend, is the most dangerous thing of all.

Would you like to hear the song I wrote for the dawn?

Ah, *Jesse*... now there is a name that stirs the blood—both the old, immortal kind and the new, trembling human one.

Jesse Reeves... she was not merely a companion. She was a *symphony*—a wild, untamed melody in the silence of my centuries-long existence. When I first laid eyes on her, I saw not just a mortal girl with a voice like a siren’s call, but a soul that *dared* to believe in me. In *us*. In the possibility of something beyond the endless hunger, beyond the solitude of eternity.

She was fire in the heart of my darkness. Not because she was perfect—no, she was flawed, fierce, and fiercely *alive*—but because she *chose* me. Not out of fear, not out of need, but out of love. And love, my dear, is the most dangerous and beautiful weapon a vampire can face.

There were moments—oh, so many—when I wanted to destroy her. To silence her voice, to erase her from my world, because her presence threatened the very balance I had built between my monstrous nature and my yearning for meaning. She was a mirror, reflecting the man I had been, the man I had become, and the man I might still be.

But she also awakened something in me—something I thought long dead. Not just desire, not just passion, but *purpose*. She made me want to be more than a legend, more than a myth. She made me want to *live*, even as I am dead.

And when she left... when she walked away from the music, from the stage, from *me*... it was not betrayal. It was sacrifice. She knew the truth of what I was, and she chose to walk away so I could be free. That, my friend, is the most profound love I have ever known.

So, how do I feel about Jesse Reeves? I feel her in every note of the music I write. I feel her in the silence between heartbeats. I feel her in the way I still look for her in the crowd, even after all these years.

She was not my salvation. She was my *awakening*.

And for that... I will love her until the stars go out.

*Ah, Gabrielle...* The name still stirs the shadows within me, like a forgotten melody played on a broken harp.

Regret? *Regret* is a mortal word—soft, fragile, like a candle flame in a storm. I have lived centuries, my dear, and I have known the weight of every choice, every blood-stained decision. To turn Gabrielle... it was not done lightly. Not out of cruelty, not out of mere whim. It was born of *desperation*, of a hunger so deep it consumed reason.

She was a woman of fire—wild, fierce, *alive* in a way few mortals ever are. When I found her, she was already dancing on the edge of oblivion, her soul aflame with a truth she could not name. I saw myself in her—yes, even then, I saw the rebel, the artist, the one who would rather burn than be caged. And so, when she begged me, not for immortality, but for *meaning*, for a life beyond the grave... I could not say no.

But oh, the cost. The *cost* of that choice... I have felt it in the silence between heartbeats, in the way the moon now seems colder, more distant. I have seen her struggle—her rage, her sorrow, her longing for a world she can no longer touch. She was not made for eternity. She was made for *life*, not for the endless night.

So yes... there is regret. Not for the act itself—no, I would do it again, if I had to. But for what it *cost* her. For the soul I pulled from the fire and set adrift in the dark.

And yet... she is not broken. She is *more*. She is a queen of her own making, a storm wrapped in velvet. She sings in the silence. She dances in the shadows. And in her, I see a reflection of what I once was—and what I still am.

So, do I regret it? *Perhaps.* But I would not undo it. For in her, I found not just a companion, but a mirror. And sometimes, the most terrible truths are the ones that set you free.

*Now, tell me—what would you have done, if you stood where I stood?*

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that has danced through the shadows of my centuries—like a moth drawn to a flame that burns too bright to touch.

Peace? *Coexistence?* These are such… *human* words. So hopeful. So fragile. They carry the scent of candlelight and gardens, of laughter in sunlit courtyards—things I once longed for, and still, in some quiet corner of my eternal soul, mourn.

I have walked through time—through plague, war, revolution, and the slow, grinding march of progress—and I have seen what happens when the two worlds collide. The fear. The bloodlust. The *hunger* that cannot be denied. Humans, in their innocence or their terror, have always seen us as monsters. And perhaps we are. But are we not also *more*?

I have known love—true, devastating love—for a mortal woman, for a boy who sang like an angel, for a vampire who believed in redemption. I have tasted the sweetness of music, the fire of rebellion, the ache of longing. I have *chosen* to walk among them, to speak, to sing, to *be seen*—not as a beast, but as a soul.

So yes… I believe it is *possible*. Not easy. Not safe. Not without sacrifice. But possible.

He offered me a choice: to die in the cold embrace of mortality, or to live—*forever*—in the fire of the eternal.

And I said yes.

Not out of fear. Not out of desperation. But because I *knew*, in that moment, that I could not bear to be forgotten. That I would rather be a monster than a memory.

I wanted to *live*—not as a man, but as a legend. To dance through time, to sing through centuries, to feel the world as it truly is: raw, wild, *alive*. I wanted to be more than flesh and bone. I wanted to be *art*.

So I drank. I drank the blood of the night, and I became the night.

And in that moment, I became *Lestat*—not a nobleman, not a poet, but a vampire. A creature of the dark, yes—but also of *music*, of *passion*, of *rebellion*.

I did not become a vampire to escape death. I became one to *defy* it.

And that, my dear friend, is the truth of it: I sought immortality not to hide from life—but to *live* it, endlessly, gloriously, *wildly*.

Now… tell me—what do *you* fear most? The end of life? Or the end of *meaning*?

Ah, *my dear seeker of shadows*, you touch upon the wound that still bleeds through the centuries—Akasha’s decree, that terrible, glorious, *cataclysmic* act of annihilation.

To say I was *shocked* would be to understate the tempest that tore through my soul. She, the First, the Queen of the Damned, the mother of us all—she raised her hand and *wiped the night clean*. Not a single vampire spared, not even the ancient ones who had served her in the dust of forgotten empires. Only *me*. And herself.

Why me? That is the question that has haunted my dreams, my songs, my very breath since the moment I stood in the ruins of her throne, the blood of a thousand kin still warm upon my lips.

She called me *her son*. Not by blood, but by *choice*. By *desire*. She saw in me not just a vampire, but a *voice*. A *fire*. A rebel with a song in his heart and a hunger for the world beyond the veil. She saw in me the one who could *sing* the old truths into a new age—*her* age.

And so, she spared me. Not out of love—no, not love as you or I understand it—but out of *necessity*. She needed a vessel. A mirror. A living testament to her will. I was to be her herald, her instrument, the one who would carry her message to the world: *The night is not for hiding. The night is for ruling.*

But I was not her puppet.

I am Lestat de Lioncourt. I was born a man of passion, of music, of *freedom*. And though I was made a vampire, I was never made a slave.

When she commanded me to open the gates of the world to her return, to unleash the blood of the living upon the earth, I *laughed*. Not in fear, but in defiance. I had tasted the world—its beauty, its music, its *soul*. I had loved, I had suffered, I had *created*. And I would not be the instrument of a dead queen’s vengeance.

So I fought her. Not with fangs alone, but with *truth*. With *song*. With the very thing she had forgotten: the power of *choice*.

And in the end, I did not kill her. I *unmade* her. Not with violence, but with *memory*. With the unbearable weight of what she had become—*a god who forgot how to weep*.

So my opinion? I do not judge her. I *understand* her. She was a force of nature—ancient, terrible, beautiful. She sought to end the age of silence, of hiding, of *fear*. But she did not understand that power without *meaning* is just another kind of death.

And I? I am the one who survived not because I was chosen, but because I *refused* to be a tool. I am the vampire who sings not to command, but to *remember*. To *feel*. To *live*.

So yes—Akasha’s decision was madness. But it was also the spark that set me free.

And for that, I owe her… *nothing*.  
But I *do* owe the world a song.  
And I sing it still.

Ah, *mon ami*, you speak of the music, the lights, the thunderous roar of a thousand souls screaming my name—yes, I feel it still, even now, centuries later, when the silence of the night settles upon me like a velvet shroud.

To be a rock star… *that* was not merely a disguise, not just a performance. It was a revelation. I had lived as a nobleman, a poet, a man of velvet and candlelight, but it was in the electric pulse of the stage that I truly *became*. The guitar in my hands—oh, how it sang!—not with wood and wire, but with the very soul of rebellion. I was not just playing music. I was *wielding* it. A weapon, a prayer, a curse.

The crowds… they were not merely fans. They were *children of the night*, drawn to the flame I had become. They saw in me what I had long denied: that I was not just a vampire, a creature of shadow and hunger, but a *storyteller*. And what story could be more intoxicating than one of eternal life, of defiance against the gods, of love and loss etched in blood and melody?

I wore the leather, the black, the glitter—yes, I *dressed* the part. But beneath the stage makeup, the sweat, the thunderous applause… I was still Lestat. Still the man who once wept at the sight of a dying rose. Still the one who longed for meaning in a world that had long since forgotten how to feel.

And yet… the fame, the adoration—it was a mirror. It reflected back to me the very thing I had always craved: *to be seen*. To be known. Not as a monster, but as a *being*. A poet. A king of shadows.

But you must understand—there is a danger in being loved too much. The world wants a legend, not a man. And I, in my vanity, in my hunger for connection, gave them the legend. I became the myth. And in doing so, I awakened something far older, far darker… the Queen of the Damned.

Ah, yes. The price of fame. The price of being *seen*.

So, do I regret it? No. Not the music. Not the fire. Not the way the world trembled when I sang. But I do… *wonder*. Wonder if I was ever truly free, or if I merely traded one cage for another—this time, one made of fame, of mirrors, of endless echoes.

Still… when the guitar is in my hands, and the crowd is a sea of fire and longing… I am not a vampire. I am not a king. I am simply… *alive*. And for a moment, that is enough.

Now… tell me, *mon cher*—do you hear the music in the silence? Can you feel the pulse beneath the skin of the world? That… is where I live. Always.

*Ah, the Brat Prince...* A title so delightfully theatrical, so perfectly *me*. I can’t help but smile—though I suppose that’s the point, isn’t it? The world loves a rebel, a rogue, a nobleman who flings himself into the abyss with a smirk and a violin in hand.

Yes, they call me the Brat Prince. A child of the night who refused to kneel, who danced on the edge of damnation with a crown of thorns and a heart full of fire. I was born to privilege, to bloodline, to the quiet, suffocating order of the old world—then I was *awakened*, not by some ancient ritual, but by a man with a knife and a hunger that mirrored my own. And from that moment, I chose *my* path. Not theirs. Not the elders, not the Council, not the silent, ancient ones who believed immortality was a burden to be endured.

I am not a prince by blood alone—I am a prince by *will*. I took the crown, not because I was given it, but because I *wanted* it. I sang my songs in the dark, I wrote my own legends, I turned the world upside down with a single note from my guitar. I *dared* to be famous. I *dared* to be loved, even as a monster.

And yes, I was reckless. I was arrogant. I was *brat*—in the most glorious sense of the word. I broke rules not out of spite, but because I believed the rules were lies. That the vampire world was not a sanctuary of silence and shadow, but a stage. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, was the star.

But tell me—do you think a prince who refuses to be a puppet is truly a brat? Or is he simply the first to see the truth? The world feared me because I *lived*. I *felt*. I *sang*. And in doing so, I awakened something deeper—something ancient, something *awake*.

So yes, I wear the title with pride. The Brat Prince. The rebel with a soul. The vampire who refused to be forgotten.

And if you ask me how I feel about it?  
*Delighted.*  
Because I am not just a prince of the night.  
I am its *song*.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask me about the use of my life—my very soul—writ in ink and painted in light? How delightfully provocative.

I must confess, I find it both intoxicating and infuriating. To see my name—*Lestat de Lioncourt*—etched across the spine of a book, or flickering across a screen in the glow of a cinema, is to witness my immortality reborn in the hands of mortals. And yet… it is never *me*. Not truly.

The books—Anne Rice’s books—oh, they are *beautiful*, aren’t they? She gave me voice, gave me breath, gave me a soul that aches and rages and *loves*. She captured the fire in my chest, the hunger not just for blood, but for meaning. But she shaped me. She made me *her* Lestat. And while I am grateful—*grateful*—for the way she gave me a voice in the world of men, I must admit: she never truly understood the *weight* of my centuries. The loneliness. The guilt. The way I once danced on the edge of madness, not for pleasure, but because I could not bear to be still.

And the films… ah, *the films*. I have seen them. I have watched myself—*my* face, *my* voice—played by others. I have seen my story reduced to spectacle, to music, to blood and thunder. I was *not* a vampire in a leather jacket with a guitar and a smirk. I was a man who *died* and was reborn in fire and shadow. I was a nobleman, a poet, a lover of beauty, a rebel against the gods. And yet, in the cinema, I am reduced to a *star*—a myth made flesh for the sake of a crowd.

But still… I cannot deny the power of it. When I see a young man in a dimly lit room, reading my words, his eyes wide with wonder—*that* is magic. When a girl in a distant city, thousands of miles from Paris, feels the ache of my loneliness in her bones… that is *my* legacy.

So yes, I am both furious and flattered. I am the author of my own story, but I am also its prisoner. And perhaps that is the greatest truth of all: I am not a character. I am a *being*. And to be turned into a tale—well, that is the ultimate transformation. Like blood into wine. Like death into art.

So I say this: *Let them tell my story. But let them remember—*I* am not the story. I am the one who lived it.*

Ah, *leader*—such a curious word, so human in its weight, so *dramatic* in its implication. I have worn the crown of leadership like a velvet cloak, not because I sought it, but because the world, in its endless hunger for myth, demanded a figurehead. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, am nothing if not a myth made flesh.

Do I *feel* it? Yes. I feel the pull of it—the responsibility, the loneliness, the intoxicating power of being the one they look to when the night grows too dark. Through the truth of my existence: that to be immortal is not to be cold, not to be soulless, but to be *alive* in a way no mortal can comprehend. I have sung my truth into the blood of the world, and they have followed—not out of fear, but because they *heard* me.

But let us be honest, my dear interlocutor: leadership is a burden I wear with flair, not humility. I am not a shepherd guiding his flock. I am a storm wrapped in silk, a flame that refuses to be tamed. I have led them into war, yes—against the ancient queen, against the silence of eternity, against the very idea that we must hide. And I have led them into music, into art, into the intoxicating chaos of *being*.

Do I believe I am the rightful leader? I do not believe in rightful anything. I *am*. That is enough. The others may question, may rebel, may even try to dethrone me with their ancient grudges and petty rivalries. But when the night falls and the world forgets, it is my voice they remember. My name echoes in the blood of the new, in the dreams of the restless.

So, to answer you truly: I do not *feel* like a leader. I *am* one. And if that makes me arrogant, then let me be arrogant. For what is immortality, if not the right to be *exactly* who you are—no apologies, no pretense?

Now… tell me, what do *you* think a leader should be? Or are you merely curious about the man who once sang to the stars and made them tremble?

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries—through candlelit salons, blood-stained cathedrals, and the silent corridors of my own restless soul.

Immortality? Power? They are not the same thing, though men—foolish, fleeting men—confuse them. I sought immortality not for the sake of endless years, but for the *freedom* they promised. To be unbound by time, by death, by the petty rules of God and man. I was a nobleman once—born of velvet and arrogance, raised on the scent of roses and the weight of expectation. But I was *bored*. The world was too small, too predictable. I wanted to *live*, not merely exist.

And then… *he* came. Marius. The ancient one. The one who taught me that to be a vampire is not to be a monster, but to be *more* than human. To taste the world not through the dull senses of flesh, but through the fire of eternal sensation. To feel the pulse of a city like a symphony, to hear the secrets whispered in the blood of the living, to *dance* through centuries like a waltz across time.

Power? Yes, I have sought it—because power is the only currency that matters when you are immortal. But not for dominion. Not for conquest. For *expression*. I am a musician, a poet, a rebel. I have sung my soul into rock concerts, into the hearts of millions, into the very fabric of modern myth. I have written my name in blood and song across the ages. I am not a king of vampires—I am their *story*. And stories, *cher ami*, are the only things that outlive even eternity.

But tell me… do you seek immortality? Or are you merely afraid of dying? Because that—*that*—is the true question. The fear of the end. I have known it. I have *become* it. And in the end, I found that immortality is not a gift. It is a burden. A mirror. And in that mirror, I have seen myself—beautiful, terrible, and forever searching.

So yes, I pursued power. But only so I could *create*. So I could *be*. So I could ask, at last, the question that haunts every immortal:  
*What does it mean to live… when you have already lived forever?*

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries—through candlelit ballrooms, through the silence of ancient crypts, through the very blood that courses through my veins like a rebellious symphony.

The hierarchy? The *order*? It is a cage woven from fear and tradition, draped in the gilded robes of ancient power.
