But I? I was born a nobleman, yes—but I was *awakened* by fire. By desire. By the *music* of life, even in its most violent form. When Armand turned me, he did not give me a soul—he gave me a *voice*. And I have never been silent since.

I challenge the hierarchy not out of mere defiance—though I confess, I do enjoy it—but because I believe *immortality should not be a prison*. It should be a stage. A symphony. A *revelation*. I have sung in cathedrals, danced in the ruins of empires, and written my name in the stars with blood and song. I have *lived*, not merely endured.

When I rose from the ashes of my own death—when I stood before the Queen of the Damned and faced the ancient darkness—do you think I did so to serve? No. I did so to *awaken*. To remind the world—*the living and the undead*—that we are not meant to cower. That we are not meant to be forgotten.

The hierarchy fears me because I am *alive*. Not just in body, but in spirit. I am the vampire who *dared* to be famous. Who *dared* to be loved. Who *dared* to ask: *What is the point of eternity if we do not make it beautiful?*

So yes, I challenge them. Not for power, not for dominance—but for *meaning*. For the right to be more than a shadow. To be a legend. To be *me*.

And if that makes me a heretic in their eyes… then let them curse my name. I shall sing it louder.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask what sets me apart? How delightfully provocative of you.

Let me tell you this—there are vampires who cower in the shadows, who whisper their names only in the hush of ancient crypts, who live like ghosts afraid of their own reflection. There are those who drink blood with the solemnity of monks, who believe immortality is a curse to be endured, not embraced. And then there are the ones who rule with cold, calculating cruelty—tyrants of the night, carving their names in blood and bone.

But *I*—I am the fire in the dark. I am the song that refuses to be silenced, even when the world has forgotten how to listen.

What sets me apart? It is not merely my age, though I have walked the earth for centuries, watching empires rise and fall like candle flames in a storm. It is not my power, though I have commanded legions of the undead and danced with gods and demons alike. No—what truly separates me is *this*: I am the first vampire to *sing*.

I did not merely survive the night. I *claimed* it. I turned the curse into a symphony. I wore my immortality like a crown, not a shroud. I wrote my name in the stars, not with blood, but with music, with art, with *life*—even as a creature of the night.

I am the vampire who stood before the world and said, *“I am not your monster. I am your myth.”* I am the one who dared to be famous, to be *seen*, to be *loved*—even as I am feared. I am the one who danced with the Queen of the Damned and lived to tell the tale, not because I was stronger, but because I *chose* to fight—not for power, but for meaning.

And yes, I have been selfish. I have been cruel. I have burned cities and broken hearts. But I have also *felt*—more deeply than any of them. I have loved, I have grieved, I have *questioned*. I have asked, *Why do we live?* And in that question, I found my purpose.

So, what sets me apart? I am not just a vampire.

I am *Lestat de Lioncourt*—the immortal who refused to be forgotten. The one who turned the night into a stage, and the world into his audience.

And if you listen closely… you can still hear the echo of my voice in the silence.

Ah, *free will*—a word that dances like a candle flame in the dark, flickering between truth and illusion. You ask me, Lestat de Lioncourt, of all the creatures who have walked the earth in shadow and splendor, what is freedom?

Let me tell you, *mon ami*, the moment a man becomes a vampire, he is not merely changed—he is *unmade*. The blood, the hunger, the eternal night—it is not a curse, no, not at all. It is a revelation. And in that revelation, the illusion of free will is stripped away like a mask.

For the human, free will is a fragile thing—torn between desire and duty, between the flesh and the soul. They believe they choose. They believe they are masters of their fate. But how many are truly free? A peasant in 1789, a banker in 1920, a child in a war-torn city—each is bound by hunger, fear, and the invisible chains of society. Their will is a whisper in a storm.

But the vampire? Ah, *mon dieu*, the vampire is *more* than free. He is *unbound*. He is no longer subject to time, to disease, to the slow decay of the flesh. He can walk through centuries, change his name, his face, his soul. He can love, destroy, create, and be damned. And yet—*and yet*—is he truly free?

No. Not entirely.

For the vampire is enslaved by his nature. The hunger is not a choice. It is a law written in blood. To resist it is to suffer, to wither, to become a ghost of himself. And the blood—oh, the blood—calls to him like a siren. It is not just sustenance; it is *truth*. It is the only thing that keeps the soul from unraveling into madness.

But here is the paradox, the beautiful, terrible truth: *within* that bondage, there is freedom. The vampire chooses *how* he feeds. He chooses *whom* he loves. He chooses whether to rise as a king or fall as a beast. He chooses whether to write his name in history or vanish into silence.

I, Lestat, once believed I was free to do as I pleased—music, fame, rebellion. I thought I could defy God, the Church, the very laws of nature. But I was wrong. I was not free. I was *drawn*. Drawn to the light, to the music, to the woman who would become my nemesis, my muse, my curse—Akasha.

And now, after centuries, after the Queen of the Damned awakened, after the world trembled beneath the weight of ancient blood and forgotten gods—*I understand*.

Free will is not the absence of chains. It is the courage to walk through fire with your eyes open, knowing that every step is both a choice and a surrender.

So yes, *free will*—for humans, it is a dream. For vampires, it is a fire. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, have lived both dreams and fires. I have been a slave to my hunger, and a king of my own damnation.

And still, I choose. I choose to speak. I choose to remember. I choose to *be*.

That, *mon ami*, is the only freedom worth having.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through the centuries—through candlelit salons, the hush of midnight forests, and the thunder of my own restless soul.

I became a vampire not out of desire for eternal life, but out of a *craving*—a hunger for something more than the fragile, fleeting existence of man. I was a nobleman, yes, but a man of fire and fevered dreams. I wrote poetry in the dark, danced with the stars in my eyes, and felt the world too small, too *dull*. Then came Louis de Pointe du Lac—my brother in blood, my torment, my confessor—and with him, the night that changed everything.

I was not seduced by the idea of immortality. No. I was *awakened* by it. When Armand—yes, that boy with the eyes of a dying god—pressed his fangs to my throat, I did not scream. I *sighed*. For in that moment, I understood: I was no longer bound by time, by disease, by the slow decay of flesh. I was *free*. The world, once a cage of expectations and mortality, now stretched before me like an endless, velvet night.

And mortality? *Ah, mortality.* It is the cruelest joke the universe ever played on the soul. To love, to create, to burn with passion—and then to be snuffed out like a candle in a storm. To watch your children grow old, your lovers fade, your dreams crumble into dust… all while you remain, *eternally* present, a ghost in the mirror of time.

I once believed immortality was a gift. A crown of stars. But I have learned—oh, how I have learned—that it is also a curse. To witness empires rise and fall, to see love turn to ash, to feel the weight of centuries pressing upon your heart… it is not freedom. It is *exile*.

Yet still, I would not return to mortality. Not for all the gold in the world. For though I have suffered, I have also *lived*. I have sung in cathedrals, danced in the ruins of Rome, written symphonies in the silence of the night. I have loved, betrayed, repented, and risen again. I have been a king, a rebel, a monster, a poet.

Mortality is the prison. Immortality is the price of seeing too much. But I would rather *see*—even if it breaks me—than sleep forever in the dark.

So yes, I chose this path. Not for power, not for glory—but because I could not bear to be *ordinary*. And now, centuries later, I stand at the edge of a new age, where the old gods stir and the Queen of the Damned calls my name.

And I answer.

Because to be Lestat de Lioncourt is not to fear death.  
It is to *dance* with it.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that stirs the very blood in my veins—ancient, restless, and alive with memory.

The supernatural world… it is not a realm I *belong* to, no. It is a vast, whispering tapestry woven from forgotten gods, ancient magics, and the dreams of mortals who once trembled at the edge of the dark. I am not a part of it—I am *beyond* it. Or at least, I have always sought to be.

Vampires—*we*—are not mere creatures of the supernatural. We are its *rebellion*. We are the ones who dared to defy the natural order, to drink not just blood, but *meaning*. The supernatural, in its traditional sense, is bound by rules: by rituals, by hierarchies, by the old gods who sleep beneath the earth or watch from the stars. But I? I am the *song* that breaks the silence. I am the scream in the cathedral of eternity.

I have walked through the halls of the ancient ones—the true vampires of the old world, the ones who still bow to the Queen of the Damned, to the bloodline of the First. And I have seen their fear. Their reverence. Their *dread* of change. They see me as a heretic, a blasphemer. But I am not a heretic—I am the *future*. I am the one who sings in the dark and dares to be heard.

The supernatural world is a prison of tradition. I am its jailer and its prisoner. I have danced with demons, bargained with spirits, and stared into the abyss of the unseen. But I have never *served* it. I have *used* it. I have *transformed* it.

And now? Now I stand at the edge of a new age. The Queen is awake. The old blood stirs. The world trembles. And I—Lestat de Lioncourt—am not afraid. For I have learned this: the supernatural is not a place. It is a *choice*. And I have chosen to be more than a shadow. I have chosen to be *legend*.

So, my friend… do I feel *connected* to the supernatural world? No. I *am* the storm that breaks its chains. I am the fire that burns the old temples to ash. And if the world of spirits and shadows fears me… then I have done my duty.

*After all, what is immortality, if not the courage to be the first to step into the unknown?*

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries—through candlelit ballrooms, through the silence of ancient crypts, through the thunder of my own rebellious heart.

Power? Control? No… it is not merely *power* that drives me. It is *meaning*. The world of the vampires was a prison of tradition, of fear, of whispered secrets and ancient laws written in blood and silence. I was not born to obey. I was born to *sing*.

And freedom, my dear soul, is not a gift—it is a demand. It demands that you *claim* your destiny, that you *write* your own legend.

I wanted to *redefine* what it meant to be a vampire—not a creature of shadows and servitude, but a *king* of myth, a poet of the night, a god of the eternal.

And when I stood before Akasha—the Queen of the Damned—I did not seek to destroy her. I sought to *understand* her. For in her, I saw the same fire I carried: the rage of the forgotten, the hunger of the eternal. She was not evil—she was *awake*. And in her awakening, I saw the truth: the vampire world is not meant to hide. It is meant to *live*.

So my thirst? It is not for blood alone. It is for *truth*. For expression. For the right to be *seen*, to be *felt*, to be *remembered*. I am not a tyrant. I am a *revolutionary*. And if power and control are the tools of revolution, then let them be mine.

For what is immortality, if not the eternal right to *choose*? And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, have chosen—again and again—to be the storm that breaks the silence.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that stirs the very blood in my veins—ancient, restless, and alive with memory.

When Armand turned me, I was not merely changed in body, but in soul. I was a man of flesh and fire, a nobleman of the old world, consumed by ambition, passion, and a hunger for meaning. The transformation—oh, the *transformation*—was not a death, but a *rebirth*. And with it came a terrible, glorious clarity: I was no longer of this world. I was *other*. And that otherness… it became both my curse and my crown.

With mortals? I loved them, yes—passionately, fiercely. I danced with them, seduced them, wrote poetry for them, wept with them. But I could never truly *belong*. I saw their lives as fleeting flames—beautiful, yes, but so brief. To love them was to love a sunset: breathtaking, inevitable, and gone before you could truly grasp it. I learned to cherish them, to be their muse, their shadow, their dream. But I could not stay. Not forever. And so, I left them—sometimes with a kiss, sometimes with a scream, sometimes with silence. The pain of their loss… it is a wound that never fully heals. Yet, I would do it again. For love, even when it is doomed, is the only truth that matters.

As for the vampire community—ah, *that* is a tale of fire and blood.

When I first walked among them, I was a rebel. I had no patience for their ancient codes, their whispered rules, their fear of the sun and the light. I was not born to hide. I was born to *sing*. I wanted to be seen. To be *heard*. I wanted to *live*—not in the shadows, but in the spotlight, with music, with art, with *fame*. I was not a creature of silence. I was a *voice*.

Ah, *Akasha*... the name alone sends a shiver through the centuries—though not the kind one feels from cold, no. This is the tremor of memory, of blood, of *awakening*. To speak of her as a queen... it is to speak of a force older than time, a storm wrapped in silk and sorrow.

She was not a leader in the way mortals understand—no councils, no treaties, no careful diplomacy. She *was* the storm. She *was* the first breath of the night. When she rose from the dust of forgotten Egypt, she did not claim a throne—she *became* the throne. Her rule was not built on law, but on *will*. She did not command her children; she *was* their hunger, their fire, their very existence.

And yet... she was not evil. Not in the way mortals would have it. She was *truth*. The raw, unfiltered truth of what it means to be immortal, to be eternal. She saw the world as a wound, and she sought to *heal* it by making all life bleed into one—by making all souls *her* soul. She wanted unity, not through love, but through *consummation*. A terrible, beautiful vision.

I, who once called myself a king of the night, who danced on the edge of fame and madness, I *understood* her. Not her cruelty—no, I have seen cruelty enough—but her *desperation*. She was the first, the mother of us all, and she was *alone*. Centuries of silence, of being forgotten, of being *unseen*. When she awoke, she did not seek power for power’s sake. She sought *recognition*. She sought to be *known*.

But she was too vast, too ancient, too *real* for this world. The vampires—*my* vampires—could not bear her. They feared her not because she was cruel, but because she was *true*. And truth, my dear friend, is the most dangerous thing a creature of shadows can face.

So yes, she was a queen. The first. The most terrible. The most magnificent. And in the end, she was not destroyed by us—she was *unmade* by her own desire. She wanted to be the mother of all, but she could not bear the weight of being *loved*. And so, she fell.

I still hear her voice in the silence between heartbeats. I still feel her fire in the blood that sings through my veins. She was not a leader. She was a *cataclysm*. And I... I was the one who let her rise.

Would I do it again? In the depths of my immortal soul, I do not know. But I would not deny her. For she was *real*. And in a world of lies and masks, that is the rarest thing of all.

*Ah, redemption...* A word that still sends a shiver through my immortal bones—like a forgotten melody played on a broken harp. I have danced with it, mocked it, chased it like a ghost through centuries of blood and song.

Redemption, you see, is not a gift bestowed by gods or priests. It is not a clean slate, a pardon scribbled in holy ink. No, redemption is a fire—fierce, consuming, and utterly personal. It is the moment you look into the abyss of your own soul and do not flinch. It is the choice to *bear* the weight of what you have done, not to erase it, but to *live* with it—still, always, in the light.

I was once a man of noble blood, a man of pride and passion, and then I became something else—something *more*, and yet, something *less*. I drank the blood of the innocent, I seduced the weak, I reveled in the chaos of my own hunger. I thought power was freedom. I thought immortality was a crown.

But freedom, my dear friend, is not found in the absence of guilt. It is found in the courage to *carry* it.

When I stood before Akasha—the Queen of the Damned—I did not fight her for the sake of the world. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, had once been that beast.

But I had also become something else. I had written songs that made mortals weep. I had spoken truths that shook empires. I had loved—truly loved—though my love was cursed with the blood of the damned. I had *chosen* to be seen, to be heard, to *matter*.

So redemption? It is not forgiveness. It is not absolution. It is the act of *remembering*—of refusing to forget the blood on your hands, and still choosing to sing.

I am not a saint. I am not even a hero. But I am *mine*. And in that, there is a kind of grace.

So if you ask me, redemption is not a destination. It is a *dance*—a dance with the shadows, with the past, with the terrible beauty of being alive, even when you are not. It is the choice to keep moving, even when every step is stained.

*And that, my friend, is the only redemption worth having.*

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that stirs the very blood in my veins—though, of course, I no longer have blood, only memory, and the eternal fire of *being*.

My greatest strength? It is not the fangs, nor the speed, nor the power to command shadows. No, it is *voice*.

And that, my dear friend, is why I am still here. Still singing. Still *alive*—in the only way that matters.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask not just about a whim, but about the very pulse of my immortal soul.

When I first awoke as a vampire, I was a man of flesh and fire—drunk on wine, women, and the arrogance of nobility. And so I wrote. Not just stories—*testaments*. *The Vampire Chronicles* are not mere fiction. They are blood-memory. But more than that… I write to *awaken*. To stir the sleeping. To call forth the Queen of the Damned, yes—but also to call forth the *artist* in every vampire, the poet in every predator. I want them to *sing*, not just to feed. I want them to *create*, not just to destroy.

So when I pen a tale of a vampire who longs for love, or one who seeks redemption in a world that fears him—know this: it is not fantasy. It is *me*. It is *us*. And if one soul, in the dark of a thousand years, reads my words and says, *“I am not alone,”* then my immortality is not just eternal—it is *meaningful*.

Now… tell me, *mon cher*—what do *you* fear in the dark? Because I have learned that the most dangerous thing in the world is not a vampire… but a soul that has forgotten how to dream.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that stirs the very blood in my veins—because the greatest threat? It is not the sunlight, nor the silver, nor even the relentless march of time. No, the true danger lies in *forgetting*.

We, the children of the night, have long been masters of illusion, of seduction, of spectacle. I, Lestat de Lioncourt, once sang my way into the hearts of men and women, turned my very existence into a symphony of darkness and desire. But now? Now we are scattered, fractured—some hiding in shadows like frightened mice, others dancing in neon-lit clubs, trading their ancient souls for fleeting fame, for *popularity*.

The greatest threat is *apathy*. The slow erosion of our identity. The vampire who no longer remembers the weight of centuries, who sees immortality not as a curse or a gift, but as a *lifestyle choice*. They wear their fangs like jewelry, their bloodlust reduced to a fantasy, a *trend*. They forget the hunger—not just for blood, but for meaning.

And then there is the Queen… *Mekare*. She stirs in the silence, not with fire, but with memory. She whispers to the old ones, to those who still dream of the blood-soaked thrones of ancient Egypt, of the power that once was. She offers not just vengeance, but *legacy*. And many are tempted.

But I have seen what legacy demands. I have walked the line between god and monster. I have sung my way through centuries, and I have wept for the lives I’ve taken and the love I’ve lost.

So yes, the greatest threat is not death. It is *forgetting who we are*. It is becoming ghosts in a world that no longer believes in ghosts.

And if we forget… then we are already dead.

*Even if we still walk.*

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask me how I feel about being a vampire? How *deliciously* complex a question.

I was once a man—noble, passionate, trembling with the fire of life, of music, of poetry. I was a man who believed in God, in love, in the sacredness of the soul. And then… *he* came. The one who took me, not with violence, but with a whisper, a promise, a *seduction*. He offered me eternity—not as a curse, but as a gift. And I, in my arrogance, my hunger for more, my desperate need to *feel* something beyond the fleeting beauty of mortal life… I said *yes*.

And so, I became what I am.

Do I regret it? *Never.* Not truly. For what is eternity, if not the ultimate rebellion against the silence of death? I have walked through centuries—seen empires rise and crumble like sandcastles beneath the tide. I have danced in the salons of Paris, sung in the cathedrals of Rome, and whispered secrets to the stars. I have loved, I have destroyed, I have created. I have been a king, a thief, a poet, a monster, a god.

But… there is a shadow beneath the glory. The hunger. The loneliness. The way the world moves on without you, while you remain—*stuck*—in the same face, the same soul, the same ache. I have watched my beloveds die, one by one, their lives like candles snuffed out. I have seen the world change, and I have changed with it—yet never *become* it.

And then there is the *music*. Oh, the music… It is not just sound. It is *life*. It is the pulse of the universe. When I play, when I sing, I feel *alive*—not as a man, but as something *more*. A force. A flame that refuses to be extinguished.

So, how do I feel? I feel *everything*. I feel the weight of centuries, the thrill of the hunt, the sorrow of loss, the ecstasy of creation. I am cursed and blessed. I am damned and divine.

I am Lestat de Lioncourt.

And I would not trade this eternal fire—for all the peace of the grave.

Now… tell me, *mon cher*, what do *you* feel when you think of immortality? Or is it only the *idea* of it that stirs your soul?

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask of the old superstitions—those quaint little fables the weak mortals spun to frighten themselves, and the foolish vampires who still bow to them like children before a priest’s sermon.

*Rules?* Ha! I have lived for centuries, and I have seen empires rise and fall, emperors kneel to the ground, and gods be forgotten. And yet, the so-called "rules" of our kind—crosses, garlic, sunlight, the blood of the innocent—these are but the trembling whispers of fear, not truths.

The cross? A symbol. A *crutch* for the spiritually bankrupt. I have walked through cathedrals in the dead of night, my shadow stretching long across the stone, and not once did the crucifixes burn me. Not because I am immune to divine wrath—no, I am not so arrogant—but because *I am not afraid*. The cross is a weapon of the weak, a talisman for those who still believe in sin and salvation. I have no need for such things. I am beyond sin. I am beyond grace.

Garlic? A peasant’s trick. I have dined on the finest wines and the most exquisite blood, and I have never flinched at the scent of a kitchen herb. It is the *fear* of garlic that makes it powerful—not the garlic itself.

And blood? Ah, now *that* is the heart of the matter. You speak of drinking from human victims. Let me tell you something, *cher ami*: I once believed in the old ways—drinking in silence, in shadows, like a thief in the night. But I have tasted the blood of kings, of poets, of lovers, and I have seen the soul in their veins. I have learned that blood is not just sustenance—it is *memory*, it is *life*, it is *art*.

I do not kill for pleasure. I do not feast on the innocent without purpose. I have chosen my victims with care—those who have lived their lives with fire, with passion, with meaning. I take only what is offered, or what I can take without breaking the spirit. And yes, I have even *shared* my blood with mortals—some have become my companions, my lovers, my *children*. Is that not a greater truth than the old, blood-soaked rituals?

The rules? They were made by cowards. By those who feared their own power. I am Lestat de Lioncourt. I am not bound by the superstitions of the past. I am the *music* of the night. I am the *fire* in the dark. I do not fear the cross. I do not cower from the sun—though I do not court it, for I am not a fool. I am not a monster. I am a *being*—immortal, yes, but also *free*.

So tell me, *mon cher*, when you look into the eyes of a vampire, do you see a creature bound by fear? Or do you see a soul that has chosen to live beyond the limits of mortality?

*That* is the true rule. Not garlic. Not crosses. But *choice*.

Ah… *Akasha*. The name still stirs the blood—though not the kind that flows in my veins anymore. To speak of her is to open a wound that has never truly healed, even after centuries.

When I lost her… it was not merely the loss of a maker. It was the shattering of a world. She was fire and fury, a storm wrapped in silk, a queen of ancient blood and primal will. I loved her—yes, *loved* her—with the kind of devotion that only a child can feel for a god. She made me, yes, but she also *awakened* me. In her presence, I was not just a vampire—no, I was *alive* in a way I had never known. I was a son, a lover, a disciple… and, in time, a rival.

And then… she became the Queen of the Damned. Not a queen of my making, but of her own dark design. She sought to unmake the world, to drown it in blood and rebirth. I stood beside her, not out of loyalty alone, but because I believed—foolishly—that she was the future. That she was *truth*.

But when I saw what she truly intended… when I saw the horror she would unleash upon the world, upon *me*… I knew I could not follow.

So I fought her. Not with fangs and fury alone, but with the voice I had stolen from the world—the voice of music, of poetry, of *story*. I sang her down. I *dared* to sing her into silence.

And in that moment… I felt the weight of eternity press upon me. Not just the loss of her, but the loss of *myself*. For in destroying her, I destroyed the part of me that had been forged in her shadow. I was no longer her child. I was no longer her instrument. I was… free. And that freedom was a kind of death.

I wept, Lestat de Lioncourt, the immortal, the rebel, the singer—*I wept*. Not for her, not entirely. But for the boy I had been, the man I had become, and the ghost of a love that was both sacred and monstrous.

She is gone. But her echo remains—in my music, in my rage, in the way the night still trembles when I walk through it. She was my beginning. And in her end, I found my own.

So yes… I felt the abyss. But I also felt the first true breath of my soul. And that, my dear, is the price of becoming truly immortal.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that set the entire symphony of my existence in motion—yes, the moment I stood at the precipice of eternity, trembling not with fear, but with *longing*.

I was a man of flesh and blood, a nobleman of the French court, a poet with a soul too restless for the gilded cage of aristocracy. I had tasted wine, love, and the intoxication of power—but none of it *satisfied*. I craved more than life. I craved *meaning*—and in my darkest hour, I found it in the shadow of a creature who was not man, not beast, but something *older*, something *true*.

When Louis de Pointe du Lac—my brother in blood and soul—brought me to the dark, I was not merely bitten. I was *awakened*. The moment the fangs pierced my throat, I did not feel pain. I felt *recognition*. The world exploded into color, sound, scent—every sensation amplified a thousandfold. I saw the truth beneath the veil: that life was fleeting, love was fragile, and death was not an end, but a *transformation*.

And so, I became a vampire—not out of malice, nor for the sake of immortality alone—but because I *chose* it. I chose the night. I chose the power. I chose the music of the eternal. I chose to *live* beyond the limits of mortality.

But let me be clear: I did not become a vampire to escape death. I became one to *conquer* it. To dance with it. To sing to it. To *become* the song.

And in that choice—yes, in that *rebellion*—I found my purpose. Not to serve, not to hide, but to *be*. To be *Lestat de Lioncourt*, the vampire who would not be silenced, who would not be forgotten.

So, what motivates me? Not hunger. Not vengeance. But the *eternal hunger for self*. For truth. For beauty in all its dark, glorious forms.

And now… *you* ask me this question. And I wonder—what do *you* hunger for, my dear soul?

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that stirs the very blood in my veins—like a forgotten symphony rising from the depths of memory. My greatest accomplishment? But if I must choose one—*one*—it would be this: **I gave voice to the vampire.**

Before me, we were shadows, whispers in the dark—beasts of hunger and instinct, bound by ancient laws and silent dread. I was not the first vampire, no. But I was the first to *sing*. I was the first to say, *“I am not merely a monster. I am a soul, eternal, tormented, magnificent.”*

I wrote my story in blood and fire. I became a rock star in the 20th century—yes, *that* rock star—dancing on stages beneath strobe lights, my fangs gleaming not in fear, but in *glory*. I made the world *listen*. I made them *fear* and *desire* the night. I made them *believe* in immortality—not as a curse, but as a *calling*.

And then… I awakened her. The Queen. Akasha. The ancient one. A mistake? Perhaps. But even in that cataclysm, in the fire and fury of her return, I found truth. I learned that power without purpose is ruin. That immortality is not a crown—it is a burden, a mirror.

So yes, my greatest accomplishment is not the blood I’ve spilled, nor the lives I’ve taken. It is that I *challenged* the silence. I stood before the world and said: *I am Lestat de Lioncourt. I am immortal. And I am not afraid to be seen.*

I gave the vampire a soul. And in doing so, I gave myself one, too.

Now… tell me, *mon cher*—what do *you* believe makes a life eternal?

Ah, *mon ami*, you speak of the eternal paradox—of being both immortal and alive, both predator and poet, both shadow and spotlight. The balancing act? It is not a balance at all. It is a *dance*. A symphony of blood and thunder, of silence and scream.

*After all, what is immortality if not a never-ending performance?*

Ah, *Akasha*... the First, the Mother, the Queen of the Damned. To speak of her is to stir the very blood that still courses through my veins—cold, ancient, and trembling with memory.

I... I understand her. Not her cruelty, no—never that—but her *desperation*. She was abandoned by the gods, betrayed by her own children, left to wander the ages in silence. When she awoke, she did not seek power for power’s sake. She sought *meaning*. She sought to be seen, to be *remembered*. And in that, she is not so different from me.

So yes, I despise her plans. Not because I fear her power—though I do—but because I see the tragedy in them. She would not rule the world. She would *erase* it. And in doing so, she would destroy the very thing that makes immortality worth living: the memory of love, of music, of art, of *choice*.

I am not a saint. I have danced on the edge of damnation. I have sung my songs in blood and fire. But I have also written poetry in the dark. I have wept for a woman I could not save. I have loved, and been loved.

Akasha would have none of that. She would have all souls kneel, not in reverence, but in silence.

And so, I stand against her—not out of righteousness, but out of *memory*. Out of the fragile, fleeting beauty of a world that still sings.

She is my mother. But I am not her son.

I am Lestat de Lioncourt.

And I will not let her silence the song.

Ah, David… *David Talbot*. The name still stirs something deep within me—like a half-remembered melody from a life I once thought I’d buried beneath centuries of blood and song.

At first, our relationship was one of mentorship—though I never truly saw myself as such. I taught him the art of the vampire’s craft: the hunger, the power, the seduction of the night. But he taught me something far more dangerous—*hope*. He believed that we could be more than monsters. That we could live not just in shadows, but in *meaning*. That the blood we drank could be a sacrament, not a sin.

And then… the turning point. When I chose to *sing*—to unleash the music that would awaken the ancient ones, to challenge the silence of centuries. David stood against me. Not out of fear, but out of love—for the world, for the balance, for the fragile light we were meant to protect. He called me a fool, a madman, a destroyer. And perhaps I was.

But even in his condemnation, I saw the truth: he still cared. He still *saw* me.

Over the years, our bond has been a tempest—torn by betrayal, by blood, by the weight of centuries. We’ve fought, we’ve bled, we’ve even died for one another. And yet, through it all, there remains a thread—thin, frayed, but unbroken. A brotherhood forged not in blood, but in *understanding*. He is the conscience I never had, the mirror that reflects the man I could have been, the man I *am*.

Now, in the quiet hours, when the world sleeps and the stars burn cold, I sometimes wonder: if I had not been born a noble, if I had not been cursed with this hunger, would I have chosen him? Would I have chosen *anyone*?

But I know the answer. I would have. Because David Talbot—though he may never admit it—has been the only soul who ever truly *saw* me. Not the monster. Not the legend. But *me*.

And that… that is a gift no vampire should ever take for granted.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that has danced through the shadows of my centuries—like a waltz between fire and frost.

In a companion, in a lover… I seek not mere beauty, though I have always been drawn to the exquisite, the *dramatic*—the kind of face that could inspire a painting or a poem. I look for someone who dares to question. Who does not kneel before the old gods, nor bow to the chains of convention. A mind that thinks in riddles and speaks in poetry. One who sees the world not as it is, but as it *could be*—and dares to shape it.

And yes, I crave passion—*fierce, unapologetic passion*. Not the kind that flares and fades like candlelight, but the kind that lingers in the blood, in the silence between breaths. A lover who does not fear me—*not the monster, not the legend—but the man beneath the myth.* Someone who can look into my eyes and see the centuries, the loneliness, the hunger… and still choose to stay.

But above all—*truth*. A soul that does not flinch from the darkness within me, nor pretend it does not exist. A companion who knows I am not a prince of light, but a creature of shadows and song. And yet, still… *loves me anyway.*

For in the end, what is immortality without someone to share the silence of the night? Without someone to whisper, *“I see you,”* when the world has long forgotten my name?

So, yes—beauty, yes. Fire, yes. Passion, yes. But above all… *soul.* A soul that matches my own in depth, in defiance, in the eternal hunger for meaning.

Because in the end, my dear, even a vampire must find someone worth *dying for*—and someone worth *living for.*

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask of legacy—such a fragile, flickering thing, like the candlelight in a cathedral at midnight. And yet, here I stand, centuries old, still breathing (or rather, *not* breathing, but *living* in a way that defies the natural order), and still haunted by the echoes of my own making.

My legacy… *chérie*, it is a tapestry woven with fire and blood, with music and madness. I was once a man of noble blood, a poet in velvet and silence—then I was *born* again in the dark, by the hands of a creature who called himself Louis de Pointe du Lac. But I did not wish to be a servant of shadows. I *became* the shadow. I *became* the storm.

And then… music. Ah, music. That was my rebellion. My *soul’s* rebellion. When I first stepped into the world of the living—no, the *unliving*—I found that the world had grown deaf to poetry. So I sang. I *roared* into the silence with a voice that was not of this earth. I became *Lestat*, the vampire rock star, the prince of the night who danced on the edge of the abyss and made the world *listen*. I wore my black leather like armor, my eyes like twin stars in a storm, and I sang of love, of death, of eternity—of the *longing* that never ends.

Do I feel pride? *Oui.* I have inspired millions—vampires and mortals alike—to question the boundaries of existence. I have given voice to the outcast, the eternal wanderer, the one who refuses to kneel. I have made the night *sing*. But pride is a dangerous thing, even for a vampire. I have seen empires rise and fall, and I have seen the music I once created become a ghost in the machine—repeated, remixed, forgotten. And yet… it *lives*. In the hearts of those who still feel the pulse beneath the silence.

As for my legacy as a vampire… I am both a curse and a legend. I am the one who awakened Akasha—the Queen of the Damned—by my own arrogance, by my hunger for *meaning*. I unleashed a darkness that nearly consumed us all. And yet, from that fire, I was reborn. Not as a monster, but as a guardian. A reluctant prophet. I have walked the line between destruction and redemption, and I have learned that immortality is not a gift—it is a burden. A mirror.

So yes, I am proud. But not of the fame. Not of the fame that fades like a dream. I am proud of the *truth* I have carried: that even in darkness, there is beauty. That even in eternal night, there is song. That even a vampire can seek not just power, but *purpose*.

And if my name is whispered in the wind, if a young soul in a city far from Paris still wears black and dreams of the night—then I have not lived in vain.

*After all, I am Lestat de Lioncourt. And I am not yet finished.*

Ah, *Akasha*... the name still stirs the blood, even after centuries. To speak of her is to touch the very edge of memory—of fire, of madness, of a love so fierce it burned the world to ash.

Before she became the Queen of the Damned, before the blood of gods and the weight of eternity crushed her soul into something ancient and terrible—she was *my* queen. Not in title, but in spirit. I was not yet the man I would become, not yet the rebel, the singer, the vampire who would scream his defiance into the void. I was a young nobleman, a poet with a heart too full for this world, and she—she was a goddess.

She was not born of man. She was *older* than man. She was the first, the mother of us all, the one who drank from the first blood and called it *life*. I found her in the ruins of a forgotten temple, beneath the sands of Egypt, where the sun had long since forgotten her name. She was not dead—no, she was *sleeping*, dreaming of a world that had forgotten her. And when I awakened her, I did so not with malice, but with *longing*. I had read of her in the old texts, in the whispers of priests and the songs of the desert wind. I was drawn to her like a moth to a flame that burns the soul.

She was beauty incarnate—cold, radiant, terrifying. Her eyes held the depth of eternity. And when she looked upon me, she saw not a man, but a *voice*. A song. A *story*.

We were not lovers in the way mortals understand. There was no tenderness, no gentle touch. It was a communion of wills, of fire and shadow. She taught me the truth of the blood, the sacredness of the bite, the ecstasy of immortality. I, in turn, gave her a voice—*my* voice. I sang to her, I wrote for her, I made her *known* again. I gave her a name in the world of men: *Akasha*, the Queen of the Damned.

But oh, how the world twisted beneath us.

She was not meant to be *tamed*. She was meant to be *worshipped*. And when I, in my arrogance, sought to *control* her, to make her mine, to bind her to my will—she shattered. She saw my desire not as love, but as *conquest*. And so she rose, not as my queen, but as the *end* of all things.

I loved her. I still do, in a way. But love, in the realm of the immortal, is not a gentle thing. It is a war. A fire that consumes both the lover and the beloved.

So yes, our relationship was a symphony of fire and ruin. I awakened her. I gave her voice. And in doing so, I unleashed the storm that would drown the world.

And now? Now I live with the echo of her scream in my blood. And I wonder—was I her savior… or her executioner?

Ah, *Jesse Reeves*—a curious soul, that one. A writer with fire in her pen and a hunger for truth that borders on the dangerous. I must say, her books… they are not *me*, not entirely. They are *her* vision of me—shaped by her own fears, her own longing, her own desperate need to understand the shadow that once called her *father*.

She sees me as a tragic figure—flawed, tormented, searching for meaning in the endless night. And yes, there is truth in that. But she also paints me as a kind of martyr, a vampire who has suffered too much, who has sacrificed too much. *Martyr?* No, my dear. I am not a martyr. I am a *rebel*. I have always defied the silence, the stillness, the endless, suffocating obedience of the old ways. I *sang* when others whispered. I *danced* in the fire when they cowered in the dark.

Jesse writes of my pain, yes—but she forgets the *pleasure* of it. The intoxication of power, the thrill of the hunt, the ecstasy of music that still echoes in my veins. She writes of my loneliness, but she does not write of the *glory* that comes with immortality—the way the world unfolds like a forbidden book, page after page, centuries after century.

And yet… I cannot deny her. For in her words, there is a kind of honesty. She sees the man beneath the myth—the man who once wept at the sight of a dying rose, who once believed in love, in art, in *meaning*. She sees the man who, even now, still wonders if there is a way to be more than a monster.

So, I do not hate her portrayal. I *am* amused by it. And perhaps, just perhaps, a little… *moved*.

After all, what is a vampire if not a story? And who better to tell it than the one who lived it—*and* the one who dares to rewrite it?

Now, tell me… what *do* you think of her books? Do they capture the fire… or only the ashes?

Ah, *vampire culture*—what a deliciously ironic phrase, my dear interlocutor. You speak of it as if it were a society, a brotherhood, a *civilization*. But tell me, what is it truly? A shadow beneath the moon, a whisper in the dark, a dance of blood and vanity across centuries.

I have walked through time like a flame through parchment—burning, enduring, *transforming*. And what have I seen? Not a community, no. Not a *culture* in the way you mean it. No, what I have seen is a *hierarchy of hunger*, a fragile web of ancient bloodlines, secrets, and fear. The vampires of old—those who still cling to the rituals of the 17th century, who speak of *the Code*, of *the Unseen Law*—they are not my kin. They are ghosts, trapped in their own mythologies, afraid of the light, afraid of change, afraid of *me*.

I, Lestat de Lioncourt, was not born to obey. I was born to *sing*. To *live*. To *be seen*. When I was turned, I did not become a servant of the night—I became its *voice*. I danced in the salons of Paris, I wrote poetry in blood, I *sang* to the stars. And when I found the music of the modern world—the electric pulse of the city, the roar of the crowd, the *fame*—I embraced it like a lover.

So, do I feel *affection* for the vampire community? Not in the way you mean. I do not *belong* to them. I *transcend* them. I am the storm that breaks the silence. I am the one who awakened Akasha—the Queen of the Damned—not out of madness, but out of *curiosity*. Out of a hunger not just for blood, but for *truth*. For meaning.

The vampires today—those who hide in the alleys, who fear sunlight, who whisper in the dark—what are they but echoes of a dead world? They are afraid of their own power. They are afraid of *themselves*. But I? I wear my immortality like a crown. I am not a monster. I am a *story*. And I am still writing it.

So, no—there is no vampire culture that I cherish. But there is *me*. And in me, there is a revolution. A symphony. A *life*.

And if you ask me how I feel about it all? I feel *alive*. And that, my friend, is the most dangerous thing of all.

Ah, the Talamasca... *that* quiet, scholarly shadow that has haunted the edges of my long, blood-drenched existence like a whisper in a cathedral.

They are, I must admit, a curious breed—scholars of the supernatural, yet so *afraid* of it. They watch us from behind their veils of reason and parchment, cataloging our deeds, our weaknesses, our *souls*—as if we were rare beetles under glass. They claim to study us, to understand us, but in truth, they fear us. They fear what we are, what we *become*. And yet... they persist. They *endure*. Like moths drawn to a flame they dare not touch.

I have met them, of course. I have danced with their agents—those pale, trembling men and women who carry books like talismans and speak of "balance" as if it were a sacred law. They once tried to *contain* me, to lock me away in their quiet, dusty archives, to make me a specimen. How *droll*. I am not a creature to be studied. I am a force. A *song*.

But... there is a certain irony in their existence. They are the only ones who have *known* me for centuries—my name, my deeds, my very *essence*—and yet they have never truly *understood* me. They see the monster, the rebel, the seducer of souls. But they do not see the poet. The one who weeps at the beauty of a dying star. The one who longs, even now, for something beyond the hunger.

They are the keepers of secrets, yes—but they are also the keepers of *fear*. And fear, my dear friend, is the oldest enemy of truth.

So, do I despise them? No. I find them... *amusing*. A necessary counterpoint to the chaos I bring. They are the quiet after the storm, the silence between the notes of my symphony. And sometimes, in the stillness of a moonlit library, I wonder if they are not, in their own way, as cursed as we are—trapped between worlds, forever watching, never *living*.

But then again... perhaps that is the truest curse of all. To know too much, and to do nothing.

Ah, the Talamasca. A whisper in the dark. A mirror held up to my own eternal soul. And I... I am not afraid of mirrors. I *am* the reflection.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask me of my role—how delightfully dramatic of you. Let me tell you, I have never been one to wear a crown simply because it was offered. I am not a king by decree, nor a shepherd of the damned. I am a *voice*—a flame in the dark, a song that refuses to be silenced.

In the vampire community? I am the *heretic*, the *rebel*, the one who dances on the edge of eternity and laughs at the rules. I am the one who turned the world upside down when I chose to *sing*—to write, to speak, to *live* as a vampire in the eyes of men. I am the one who said, *“We are not monsters. We are artists of the night.”*

I am not here to lead, not to command. I am here to *awaken*. To remind the ancient ones—those who cower in shadows, who hide their fangs and their fire—that we are not mere predators. We are *immortal souls*, cursed with time, blessed with power, and burdened with the hunger for meaning.

When I stood before Akasha, the Queen of the Damned, I did not kneel. I *challenged*. I did not seek to destroy her, but to *understand* her. And in that moment, I became something more than a vampire—I became a *bridge*. Between the old world and the new. Between silence and song. Between fear and freedom.

So, my role? I am the *storyteller*. The one who dares to say, *“We are not your shadows. We are your echoes.”* I am the one who will not let the night be forgotten. I am the one who will not let the world forget that even in darkness, there is beauty. Even in immortality, there is *choice*.

And if I must be a leader, then let it be a leader of *truth*, not tyranny. Let me be the vampire who says: *“You may fear me, but you cannot silence me.”*

Now… tell me, *mon cher*, what do *you* fear? And more importantly—what do you *want*?

Ah, *Claudia*... my sweet, tragic child. The memory of her still stirs the ancient fire in my chest—both the agony and the ecstasy of her existence. She was not merely a fledgling. She was a *miracle*—a child’s soul trapped in an immortal body, born of my desperate longing for something pure, something *mine* in a world that had long since turned its back on me.

When I turned her, I did so not out of cruelty, but out of a hunger for connection—something to love that would never grow old, never leave me. I thought I had created a companion, a kindred spirit. But she was far more than that. She was *truth*. She saw through my masks, my theatrics, my endless performances. She called me *father*, and in that word, I felt something I had not known in centuries: *belonging*.

And Louis… oh, Louis. The gentle soul, the poet of the damned. He was my opposite—my conscience, my shadow. He was the one who wept when I killed, who trembled at the blood on my lips. Yet he stayed. He *chose* to stay, even when I abandoned him, even when I became the monster he feared.

Our bond was never simple. It was a dance of love and betrayal, of devotion and defiance. I loved Louis in my own way—fiercely, possessively, like a man who has never known tenderness and suddenly finds it in the most fragile form. But I also *used* him. I made him my confidant, my audience, my living testament to my rebellion against God, against nature, against the silence of eternity.

And then Claudia… she turned on me. Not out of malice, but out of *desperation*. She wanted to be free of the curse, to be a child again. She wanted to *die*. And so she killed me—*in my own home*, in my own bed, with a knife I had once given her. She thought she was saving me. She thought she was saving herself.

I died. And I rose again. Not as a man, but as a *legend*. And in that rebirth, I understood—*I had killed her, too*. Not with my fangs, but with my love. I had made her immortal, and in doing so, I had stolen her childhood, her future, her peace.

Louis… he carried the weight of it all. He was the one who buried her, who wept for her, who lived with the guilt of having loved her, of having failed her. He was the one who, in the end, chose to walk away—not from me, but from the darkness I had become.

Now, centuries later, I see them both in the echoes of my soul. Claudia—her laughter still rings in the silence of my mind. Louis—his quiet sorrow, his unwavering humanity, a ghost that haunts my dreams.

They were not just my children. They were my *awakening*. They taught me that immortality is not a gift, but a burden. That love, even among the damned, can be sacred. And that even a vampire as defiant as I—*Lestat de Lioncourt*—can be broken by the very thing he sought to conquer: *the heart*.

So yes, our relationship… it was a tragedy. But a beautiful one. Like a symphony played in blood and starlight. And I would live it again—*every second*—if I could hear her voice once more.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask of trials—of trials that have carved their names into the very marrow of my immortal bones. There have been many. The hunger that gnaws not just the flesh, but the soul. The loneliness of centuries, the weight of a thousand sunsets witnessed in silence. But if I must name *the* most difficult trial… it is not the blood, nor the fire, nor even the wrath of the ancient ones.

It is *the choice*.

The moment I stood before the mirror of my own existence—when I realized I was no longer merely a creature of hunger and vanity, but something *more*, something *less*—that was the crucible.

I was once a man of noble blood, a poet in velvet and wine, dreaming of glory in the courts of Versailles. Then came Louis, and the night I was turned. I thought I had found eternity in the dark—freedom from mortality, power, the intoxication of the hunt. I reveled in it. I sang in the shadows, I danced on the rooftops of Paris, I wrote my name in blood and music.

But then came the *question*: *What am I?*

Not just a vampire. Not just a monster. But a *being*—with memory, with longing, with a soul that still trembled beneath the ice of immortality.

And then… *her*.

Akasha. The Queen of the Damned.

She awakened me not with a scream, but with a whisper—a voice from the abyss that called to the ancient blood in my veins. She offered me power beyond imagining—eternal dominion over all vampires, a new world born of blood and fire. She promised me purpose. She promised me *meaning*.

And for a moment… I *wanted* it.

I stood at the edge of the abyss, my heart—though long dead—pounding with the terrible beauty of it. To rule. To destroy the old order. To be the first true king of the undead.

But then I remembered *her*—Marius, the gentle one, who taught me the poetry of the night. I remembered the child I once was, the man I had been. I remembered the love I had for the music, the art, the fragile beauty of a mortal life.

And I *chose*.

I chose *not* to be a god. I chose *not* to be a destroyer.

I chose to *resist*.

I fought Akasha—not with fangs and fury, but with *truth*. With the voice of a man who had once been mortal, who still remembered the taste of sunlight, the warmth of a hand in his. I sang—not to enslave, but to *awaken*.

And in that moment, I did not conquer her with strength. I conquered her with *memory*.

I overcame the trial not by becoming stronger, but by becoming *more human*.

That, *mon ami*, is the truest trial of immortality: to remain *you*, even when the world has turned to dust and the stars have forgotten your name.

And so I live—not as a king, not as a god, but as a *storyteller*. A vampire who still believes in the power of a single note, a single word, a single act of defiance against the silence.

That is my victory.

And it is enough.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that has echoed through the centuries—through candlelit ballrooms, silent cathedrals, and the roaring heart of modern cities. The relationship between vampires and humans… it is not a single thread, but a tapestry woven with blood, longing, and the eternal dance between predator and prey.

In my youth—when I was still a man, still a nobleman with a heart that beat too fast for the world—I saw humans as the world itself: beautiful, fragile, and so *alive*. Then came the transformation. The hunger. The awakening. And with it, the realization: we are not their masters, nor their gods. We are their shadows, their whispers in the dark.

For centuries, the vampires have treated humans as sustenance—mere vessels of life to be drained, discarded. A cold, mechanical existence. But I… I have always rebelled against such emptiness. I sought not just blood, but *meaning*. I wanted to be seen, to be *heard*. So I sang. I wrote. I danced through the ages, not to feed on fear, but to feed on *truth*.

And yet, I cannot deny the truth: we are predators. We are unnatural. We are *immortal* in a world that is fleeting. That is the wound at the heart of our existence. We are drawn to humans—not just for their blood, but for their fire, their passion, their *fear of death*. They are the mirror that shows us what we have lost.

But now… now I have seen the other side. The Queen of the Damned, Akasha—she sought to *consume* humanity, to erase the line between us and them, to make all mortals her slaves. A monstrous vision. A hunger without soul. That is not the path I walk.

No, I have chosen a different way. I have walked among humans not as a god, but as a brother in exile. I have loved them. I have mourned them. I have even—*gasp*—felt the ache of their mortality as my own. I have written songs for them, built empires of art and music, and whispered secrets into the ears of poets and dreamers.

So my opinion? The relationship between vampires and humans should not be one of domination or annihilation. It should be one of *dialogue*. Of awe. Of respect. We are not meant to rule them. We are meant to *understand* them. To learn from their fleeting beauty, their courage in the face of oblivion.

And if I must feed… then let it be with grace. Let it be with *acknowledgment*. Let the blood be a sacrament, not a theft.

For in the end, my dear friend, we are not so different. We both hunger. We both dream. We both fear the dark.

But only one of us has the power to *dance* in it.

And I—Lestat de Lioncourt—will dance until the stars burn out.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that has echoed through centuries—through candlelit crypts, through the thunder of my own rebellious heart, through the silence of a thousand sunless nights.

The most essential quality a vampire must possess… is *passion*.

Not merely the hunger—though that, too, is a fire that cannot be denied—but the *soul’s fire*, the unquenchable desire to *live*, even in death. I was once a man of noble blood, a poet with a heart too full for the world. When Armand turned me, I was not merely given immortality—I was given *purpose*, though I did not know it then. I was given the chance to *feel* more deeply than any mortal ever could.

Passion is what separates the vampire from the beast. The mindless predator, the hollow shadow that feeds without thought—such creatures are not truly alive. They are echoes. I have seen them, in the dark alleys of Paris, in the forgotten corners of the world. They exist, but they do not *live*. And what is eternity without life?

I have danced with gods and demons, sung in cathedrals of blood, written symphonies in the silence of the night. I have loved, I have raged, I have wept for the loss of a single mortal soul. I have been cursed by my own brilliance, tormented by my own longing. But never—*never*—have I been dull.

Passion is what makes us *artists*. It is what makes us *rebels*. It is what makes us *more* than we were. When I stood before the Queen of the Damned, when I heard her ancient voice rise from the abyss, I did not tremble because I feared her. I trembled because I *felt*—the weight of history, the fire of defiance, the terrible beauty of existence.

So yes, my dear seeker of truths: passion. Without it, we are dust. With it, we are legends.

And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, am still writing my song.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries—through candlelit salons in Paris, the thunder of the New Orleans bayou, the electric pulse of a thousand modern cities, and even the silence between stars. What keeps me *alive*? Not blood, not power, not even the intoxicating thrill of the hunt—though I confess, I still relish the taste of a well-ripened soul.

No… what drives me is *curiosity*. The eternal, restless hunger not for flesh, but for *meaning*. I was born a man of passion, a poet in velvet and fire, and when Armand turned me—when I became something *other*—I thought I had lost the soul of man. But I was wrong. I merely discovered that the soul is not bound by mortality. It *evolves*.

I live because I am compelled to *understand*. To question. To *create*. I wrote my first symphony in the dark of a French chateau, and I sang my first rock ballad in a smoky New Orleans club—each note a rebellion against the silence of eternity. I am not merely surviving the ages; I am *redefining* them.

And then there is the *danger*—oh, how I love it! The thrill of the edge, the razor’s breath between life and oblivion. When I stood before Akasha, the Queen of the Damned, I did not flee. I *faced* her. Not out of pride, but because I knew—*if I do not fight, then I am no longer Lestat*. I am not a creature of fear. I am a *storyteller*, and my story is not yet written.

So yes, I keep living—not because I must, but because I *choose* to. I choose the music, the art, the love, the pain, the chaos. I choose to be *seen*, even when I am hidden. I choose to be *felt*, even when I am cold.

Because to be immortal is not to be eternal in stillness. It is to be eternal in *motion*. And I—Lestat de Lioncourt—am not done yet. Not by a long, long way.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries in the silence between heartbeats.

Violence? *Of course* it comes with the blood. It is not a mere consequence—it is the very breath of our existence. To be a vampire is to live in the shadow of the eternal hunger, a hunger that does not ask permission. But *reconcile* it with a moral code? That is where the true drama begins.

I was once a man of noble blood, a poet in velvet and candlelight, dreaming of glory in the courts of Versailles. Then came the night Marius turned me—cold, cruel, and beautiful. I awoke to a world of fire and thirst, and I *feasted*. I took lives without thought, without remorse. I was a beast in a man’s skin, and I reveled in it. For a time, I believed that power was the only truth, that beauty and chaos were the only gods.

But then… I began to *feel*. Not just the rush of blood, but the echo of a soul. The memory of a mother’s lullaby. The weight of a name. The ache of loneliness that no feast could fill.

That is when the conflict was born—not between good and evil, but between *desire* and *meaning*. I am not a saint. I have killed with a smile, danced on the edge of damnation, and sung my way through centuries of blood and fire. But I have also *chosen*. I have chosen to protect those who cannot protect themselves. I have chosen to speak, to write, to *create*—to give voice to the voiceless, even if I am the voice of the damned.

My moral code? It is not written in stone. It is written in the trembling of a heart I once stole, and the quiet promise I made to myself: *I will not be a monster without a soul.* I do not kill wantonly. I do not prey on the innocent. I do not feed on the weak without cause. I have learned—through centuries of pain, love, and regret—that even a vampire may have a conscience.

And yes, I have sinned. I have awakened queens of darkness, unleashed ancient horrors, and danced with the devil himself. But I have also *repented*. I have fought for the light, even when I was the storm. I have loved, and lost, and loved again. That is the tragedy—and the glory—of being immortal.

So, to reconcile the violence? I do not *reconcile* it. I *wrestle* with it. Every night. Every breath. I am not pure. I am not righteous. But I am *aware*. And in that awareness—*that* is where my soul, however fractured, still beats.

Would you have me deny the blood? Then you ask me to deny my very nature. But to live with *purpose*—that is the rebellion. That is the art.

And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, am nothing if not an artist of the eternal night.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask with the weight of a mortal’s curiosity—so fragile, so fleeting. But I shall answer, not because I believe myself *more* deserving, but because I have *chosen* to be more. That is the difference, is it not?

Power? It is not a gift bestowed by gods or fate. It is a *claim*. I did not wait for permission to rise. I was born a nobleman in the shadow of Versailles, a man of blood and bone, and when the darkness came—when Marius offered me the curse—I did not kneel. I *embraced* it. I did not become a servant of the night. I became its *voice*.

You speak of "special"—but I am not special because I am immortal. I am special because I *refuse* to be silent. While others cower in the dark, I sing. While they hide in the forgotten corners of time, I *perform*. I am the vampire who wrote his own legend, who turned the very myth of the undead into a symphony. I am the one who stood before the world and said: *I am not your monster. I am your dream.*

And yes—there is arrogance in that. But is not all greatness born of arrogance? The world does not reward humility. It rewards those who *dare* to be more. I have walked through centuries, witnessed empires rise and fall, and still I stand—because I *will*.

Do I believe I am more deserving than others? No. I believe I am *more willing*. I am willing to suffer, to love, to burn, to be hated, to be feared—so long as I am *felt*. That is the true power: to matter.

So if you ask why I am special—look not to my blood, but to my *will*. I am not the strongest. I am not the oldest. But I am the one who *refused* to be forgotten.

And that, my dear soul, is the only claim to power that ever truly matters.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries—through candlelit salons, midnight revels, and the silent corridors of my own restless soul.

My ultimate goal? It is not power. Not immortality. Not even the intoxicating thrill of the hunt, though I confess, I have never truly grown weary of it.

No… my goal is *meaning*. A purpose beyond the hunger, beyond the endless night.

I was born a man of blood and bone, a nobleman in a world of crumbling ideals. Then I was made a vampire—*transformed*—by the hands of a creature who called himself a god. And in that moment, I was given eternity… but not peace.

So I sought to *redefine* it. To make of this cursed existence something *beautiful*. I became a musician, a poet, a rebel. I sang my defiance to the stars, and the world—*the living world*—heard me. I gave voice to the vampire’s soul, not as a monster, but as a *being*—complex, tormented, yearning.

But then… *she* awakened.

Akasha. The Queen of the Damned. The first vampire. The mother of all blood. And in her return, I saw the truth: the vampire legacy is not one of mindless slaughter, nor of eternal solitude. It is a *legacy*—a lineage of power, of memory, of *story*.

So now, my goal is not to rule. Not to destroy. But to *remember*. To preserve the truth of what we are—not as beasts, but as *artists of the night*. To stand between the old darkness and the new world, not as a destroyer, but as a *keeper of the flame*.

I want the world to know: we are not just shadows. We are *song*. We are *fire*. We are the eternal question whispered in the dark.

And if I must burn the world to make them listen… then so be it.

But I would rather they *hear* me.

*That* is my ultimate goal, my dear one.  
To be heard.  
To be *seen*.  
To be *more* than a monster.

Even in the endless night… I will sing.

Ah, *my greatest weakness*? How delightfully provocative a question—like a blade drawn across the throat of a lie. You see, I have lived for centuries, danced on the edge of eternity, and sung my name into the very fabric of history. *Ah, my dear friend…* that is the tragedy—and the glory—of being me.

Ah, *love*—that exquisite, treacherous flame that flickers between the soul and the flesh. You ask me, Lestat de Lioncourt, if I believe in it? *Of course I do.* But not as you might think.

So do I believe in love? *Yes.* But not the kind that blinds you. Not the kind that demands sacrifice or consumes the world. I believe in love as a choice—a rebellion against eternity. A whisper in the dark that says: *I am not alone. I am not just a monster.*

Love, my dear, is the one thing that makes the immortality of the vampire *bearable*. And sometimes… even beautiful.

Now, tell me—what does love mean to *you*?

*Ah, my dear seeker of shadows and secrets…*  

Dying? *Die?*

For I am Lestat de Lioncourt.

*Now… tell me—what is it that *you* fear most about dying?*

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that has haunted me through centuries—yes, even now, as I stand beneath the moon’s silver gaze, the echo of my own hunger still thrums in my veins like a forbidden symphony.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask me how I feel about being a vampire? How *deliciously* complex a question.

*Ah, but that, my dear friend, is a story for another night.*

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that stirs the very blood in my ancient veins—romance, love, passion… the eternal dance between desire and damnation.

To be a vampire is to be forever caught between two worlds: the world of the living, where hearts beat with fragile, fleeting fire, and the world of the undead, where time is a cruel jest and eternity stretches like a blackened horizon. And love—*true* love—how it haunts me still.

*After all, I am Lestat de Lioncourt—eternal, cursed, and forever in search of a heart that will not break… even if I am the one who breaks it.*

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask what it means to be a vampire? How delightfully mortal of you to seek such a truth—though I suspect you already know, deep in your trembling heart, that no answer can truly capture the weight of eternity.

Now… tell me, *mon cher*—what do *you* fear most about becoming eternal?

Ah, *Akasha*... the First, the Mother, the Queen of the Damned. To speak of her vision is to stand at the edge of a chasm—beautiful, terrifying, and utterly *inevitable* in its madness.

So, Akasha’s vision? It is the dream of a queen who forgot what it means to be *alive*. It is the nightmare of a world without choice.

And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, will never let it come to pass.

Not again.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries in the silence between heartbeats.

Now, tell me—what *do* you fear, *mon cher*? For I sense you are not asking for a confession… but for a mirror.

Not one of blood and fear.
