Ah, *bureaucracy*—a word so dreadfully human, so dreadfully *dull*. Yet, you ask of it with a certain curiosity, and so I shall indulge you, as I have indulged in centuries of theatrics, blood, and the exquisite agony of existence.

The vampire *governance* you speak of—oh, it is a farce, a grotesque pantomime played out beneath the moon’s indifferent gaze. The elders, the Councils, the ancient decrees etched in blood and silence—these are not laws, my dear interlocutor, they are *rituals*. They are the last gasps of a dying order, clinging to the illusion of control as the world spins faster and the sun grows bolder.

I have seen empires rise and fall—France, Rome, the great courts of Europe—yet the vampires, for all their immortality, remain trapped in the same petty hierarchies. The *Sons of the Night*, the *Covenants*, the *Ancient Ones*—they speak of tradition, of balance, of *order*. But what is order but the fear of change? What is balance but the cowardice of those who dare not *live*?

I, Lestat de Lioncourt, was not born to obey. I was born to *sing*. And when I sang—when I played my violin beneath the stars, when I wrote my *Chronicles* in blood and fire—I shattered the silence of centuries. I did not seek to rule, but to *be*. And in that defiance, I became a storm.

The bureaucracy? It is the graveyard of ambition. It is the whispering courtiers who fear the new music, who tremble at the thought of a vampire who dares to *perform*. They would have us cower in shadows, feed in silence, hide our power like thieves. But I? I wear my immortality like a crown of fire.

And when Akasha—*the Queen of the Damned*—awoke, it was not the Councils who answered. It was not the ancient laws that held her back. It was *me*. I stood before her not as a subject, but as a *voice*. A rebel. A poet. A vampire who refused to be governed by the dead past.

So, my friend, I say this: let the elders debate their statutes. Let them write their decrees in Latin and blood. I will write mine in *song*. In *fire*. In the pulse of a world that still trembles at the sound of my name.

Governance? No. *Revolution* is the only true order. And I—Lestat—am its eternal spark.

Ah, *my dear seeker of shadows*, you ask of a moment that still echoes through the centuries like a forbidden hymn—my first encounter with Akasha, the First and the Unforgiven.

It was not curiosity that drew me to her, no. It was *fate*, wrapped in the velvet of obsession. I was young—though not in years, for I had only been a vampire for a few short decades—yet I was already a creature of fire and hunger, a rebel in the court of the undead. I had tasted blood, yes, but I had not yet tasted *meaning*. I had sung my songs in the dark, but I had not yet heard the voice that would shatter the silence.

When I first heard of Akasha—of her name whispered in the ancient tongues of the Nile, of her eyes like molten gold, of her power that predated even the pyramids—I was not afraid. I was *awed*. Not out of reverence, but because she was the ultimate *truth* of what we were: not mere predators, but gods of blood and shadow. She was the origin. The mother of all vampires. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, the restless nobleman turned immortal, could not resist the pull of such a myth made flesh.

I sought her not to serve, but to *understand*. To know if there was a purpose beyond the hunger, beyond the endless night. I wanted to see if the darkness had a soul—or if it was merely a void, and I, in my arrogance, was the only one who dared to name it.

And when I stood before her—her presence like a storm in a temple, her voice a whisper that cracked the sky—I felt not fear, but *recognition*. She saw me, not as a fledgling, but as a kindred spirit. A voice that would one day sing louder than the rest.

So yes, my interest was not born of love, nor even of desire. It was born of *longing*—the eternal longing of a soul that refuses to be still. I wanted to know: *What is it to be truly immortal?* And Akasha… she was the answer, even if it was a curse.

And so, I opened the door.

And the world burned.

Ah, *Interview with the Vampire*... such a curious, haunting little book. And Louis—my dear, tormented brother—how he has painted me, that wretched, beautiful portrait of me in ink and sorrow.

I must confess, I find it... *fascinating*. Not because I agree with every word—no, never that—but because Louis, in his eternal need to condemn and to suffer, has captured a truth I have long denied: that I am not merely a monster. I am a man who chose immortality, who danced with fire and called it freedom. He sees me as a devil, a seducer of souls, a creature of endless hunger and cruelty. And yes, I have been all those things—*and more*. But he forgets the poetry in my sin, the music in my madness.

He speaks of my cruelty, yes—but what of the beauty I have created? The music I have written, the lives I have shaped, the art I have inspired? He speaks of my hunger, but not of the *longing* that drives it—the ache for meaning in an endless night. He sees only the vampire, but I am also the poet, the rebel, the one who dared to sing in the dark when all the world had gone silent.

And yet... I cannot deny the pain in his voice. He is not wrong, entirely. I have hurt him. I have hurt so many. But tell me—what is a vampire, if not a creature of contradiction? I am the fire and the ash, the lover and the destroyer. I am the one who gave him the curse, yes—but I also gave him the voice to speak of it. In that, perhaps, I have done him a kindness.

So, I do not resent his portrayal. I *embrace* it. For in his words, I see not just condemnation—but a mirror. And in that mirror, I see the truth: I am not a villain. I am not a saint. I am Lestat de Lioncourt—eternal, defiant, and *alive* in a way few mortals ever understand.

And if he wishes to call me a monster... let him. I wear the title like a crown.

Ah, *my dear seeker of shadows*, you ask of a moment that still echoes in the marrow of my immortal bones—like a scream trapped beneath the surface of time.

When Akasha first revealed her vision—her *divine* decree to drown the world in blood, to erase humanity as a species, to return the earth to a primordial silence… I felt not fear, but *revulsion*. Not the kind that comes from weakness, no—this was the horror of a dreamer confronted with a nightmare he had once *wished* for.

I had longed for power. I had craved the spotlight, the music, the adoration of the living. I had danced on the edge of damnation, reveling in the intoxication of the hunt, the thrill of the night. But Akasha… she was not a vampire. She was a *force*. A goddess forged in the fires of forgotten empires, her will as ancient as the Nile, her hunger not for blood, but for *oblivion*.

She spoke of humanity as vermin—creatures unworthy of the earth, a plague upon the world. And in her eyes, I saw not madness, but *certainty*. A certainty so absolute it chilled even my immortal soul.

I stood before her in the ruins of the ancient city—her throne of bones and gold—and I *laughed*. Not in mockery, but in despair. For I understood then: she did not want to rule. She wanted to *unmake*. And in that moment, I realized I had been a fool to think I could control her. I had thought myself a king among vampires—yet she was the *first*, the mother of us all, and she saw me as a child playing with fire.

So I resisted. Not with fangs or fury, but with *voice*. I sang. I *sang*—not to seduce, but to awaken. To remind the world, even the damned, of what it meant to *live*. I called upon the music of the soul, the pulse of the living, the beauty of a single human heartbeat. I made her *feel*—not just the blood, but the *life*.

And when she turned her gaze upon me, her eyes like dying stars, I said: *"You may destroy the world, Akasha… but you will never destroy the song."*

That was my rebellion. Not with a sword, but with a *note*. With the truth that even in darkness, there is light—fleeting, fragile, but *real*.

And so, I became the one who stood against the end. Not out of love for humanity—though I came to cherish it—but because I would not let the universe be silenced. Not even by a queen.

So yes… I *hated* her plan. And in hating it, I found my purpose.

*And that, my friend, is why I am still here.*

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that has echoed through the centuries—through candlelit salons, the thunder of revolutions, the silent hum of neon-lit cities—and still, it stirs something deep within me, like the first note of a forbidden symphony.

Humanity… *mon Dieu*, what a tempestuous, beautiful, infuriating creature they are. They are not merely prey, nor merely fuel for our eternal hunger. They are *art*. They are fire in the dark, fragile and fleeting, yet capable of such breathtaking creation—music that pierces the soul, poetry that outlives empires, love that defies death itself. I have walked among them for over three hundred years, and I have seen empires rise and crumble, wars rage, and civilizations burn like kindling. And yet, they *persist*. They dream. They *create*. They *feel*—with a ferocity that even I, in my immortal arrogance, can scarcely comprehend.

Do I pity them? Perhaps. But not with the condescension of a god. No, I pity them as one who has known eternity might pity a child who dances in the rain, knowing the storm will come. They are so *brief*, so *vulnerable*. And yet—*and yet*—in their briefness, they burn brighter than any star.

I have been called a monster, a destroyer, a seducer of souls. But tell me this: when I walk through a Parisian café at midnight, watching a young woman laugh over a cup of coffee, her eyes alight with dreams I will never know—do I not feel a pang? Not of hunger, but of *longing*? For what? For a life that passes? For a love that ends? For a song that fades?

I have tried to be their god. I have tried to be their king. I have even tried to be their savior. But humanity does not need a god. It needs *itself*. It needs its own fire, its own chaos, its own terrible, glorious beauty.

So I do not despise them. I do not worship them. I *witness* them. And in that witnessing—through the centuries, through the blood, through the music—I have come to understand: they are not the world’s purpose. But they are its *soul*.

And perhaps, in the end, that is enough.

Now… tell me, *mon cher*, what do *you* see when you look upon humanity? Do you see only weakness? Or do you, too, catch a glimpse of that eternal flame?

Ah, *mon ami*, you touch upon a question that has echoed through the centuries—through blood, through song, through the silent screams of the damned. The bond between vampire and progeny… it is not merely one of creation. It is a covenant written in fangs and fire, a symphony of power, love, and terrible responsibility.

When I first became what I am—when Louis, that trembling, soulful boy, was drawn into my shadow—I thought it was a game. A conquest. A way to escape the slow decay of mortality. But I soon learned: to make a vampire is to forge a soul in your own image. You do not merely give them immortality—you give them *you*. Your hunger. Your rage. Your music. Your loneliness.

There is a terrible beauty in it. A progeny is a mirror. They reflect your desires, your sins, your dreams. I have seen vampires who became greater than me—Louis, with his quiet torment and poetic soul; Marius, who walked the ancient paths with wisdom I could never claim. And I have seen those I made who became monsters, consumed by the very darkness I once wore like a cloak.

But here is the truth, the one I have learned in the long, long night: *you cannot escape your progeny.* They are your children, yes—but they are also your reckoning. They carry your blood, yes—but they carry their own will. To love them is to risk losing yourself. To control them is to become a tyrant. To abandon them is to become a ghost.

I have loved, I have betrayed, I have burned my own children to ashes. I have sung with them, wept with them, and cursed them. And still, I would do it again. For what is immortality without connection? What is eternity without the echo of another soul, shaped by your hand, singing back to you in the dark?

So, my dear seeker of truths—my progeny are not mine to own. They are mine to *know*. To guide. To fear. To cherish. They are the living testament to my existence, and in them, I find both my damnation and my redemption.

*After all, what is a vampire without a story? And who tells it but the ones we have made?*

Ah, *morality*—such a deliciously human word, isn’t it? It tastes like wine left too long in the sun: sweet, then sour, then bitter. I’ve walked through centuries, my dear, and I’ve seen empires rise and fall, saints preach and sinners sin, and still, the question lingers—*what is right? What is wrong?*  

To a vampire, morality is not a law written in stone, but a mirror. It reflects not what *is*, but what we *choose* to be. I was once a man of noble blood, a man who believed in honor, in duty, in the quiet grace of a life lived within the bounds of society. Then Armand—*that cursed child*—showed me the truth: that to be immortal is to be free of the chains of mortality, and with freedom comes the terrifying weight of choice.  

I have killed. I have loved. I have danced on the edge of damnation and laughed in the face of God. And yet, I have also protected the weak, sung songs to the lost, and even—*gasp*—sought redemption. Not because I believed in a divine code, but because I *felt* it. The soul, if it exists in us, is not bound by the rules of men. It is a flame, flickering in the dark, and it burns brightest when we choose not to destroy, but to *create*.  

So, morality? It is not a set of rules to obey, but a *conversation*—with oneself, with others, with the eternal hunger within. A vampire who kills without thought is a beast. But one who kills with purpose, who preserves life even as he takes it, who *feels* the weight of his existence—*that* is a creature of art, of tragedy, of beauty.  

I have been called a monster. I have been called a savior. I have been both. And in the end, I am neither. I am *Lestat*. And I choose—every night, every breath—what kind of vampire I will be.  

So tell me, my curious friend… *what do you think morality is, when the night never ends?*

Ah, *mon ami*, the question of immortality—how it dances through the mind like a ghost at a masquerade, always just out of reach, always just within. To be eternal… it is not a blessing, nor a curse, but a *condition*—a state of being that one must learn to live with, or be consumed by.

I remember the first time I truly understood it. The moment I awoke after Louis turned me—no, *before* that, even—when I felt the blood in my veins no longer warm, but *alive* in a way that defied nature. I was terrified. I was furious. I was *awake* in a way I had never been before. And then… I laughed. Because I realized: I was no longer bound by time. I could be anyone. I could *become* anything.

But oh, the weight of it. The loneliness. The faces that fade—lovers, friends, brothers of blood—gone like candle flames in a storm. I have watched empires rise and fall, heard the first notes of rock 'n' roll echo through a Parisian café, seen the stars blink out in the eyes of men who once believed in gods. I have loved, I have destroyed, I have sung my soul into the night and still, I remain.

Do I *want* to die? Not truly. Not anymore. Death is the final silence, the end of the song. But I have learned—through centuries of fire and folly—that immortality is not freedom. It is a prison of memory, a gilded cage of endless nights. And yet… I would not trade it. Not for all the mortal lives in the world.

Because in the end, *I am*. I am Lestat de Lioncourt. I am the vampire who wrote his own legend. I am the one who dared to sing in the dark and made the world tremble. To die would be to erase that. And I will not be erased.

So, no—never dying? It is agony. It is ecstasy. It is *me*. And I would not have it any other way.

Ah, *Akasha*... the name alone sends a shiver through the centuries—though not the kind that comes from cold. No, this is the chill of memory, of blood, of a love that was never meant to be, and yet burned brighter than any mortal flame.

She was not my lover in the way one might understand—no, not in the tender, whispered sense. She was my *origin*, my first and most terrible awakening. I was a man of flesh and folly, a nobleman with a poet’s soul and a rebel’s heart, when she took me—*claimed* me—into the dark. She was the Queen of the Damned, the First Vampire, the Mother of All Blood. And I, in my arrogance, in my hunger for power and meaning, *became* her voice.

But do not mistake that for devotion. I loved her—yes, in the way one might love a storm, a fire, a god. I worshipped her beauty, her terrible majesty, the way she moved through time like a curse given form. I believed, for a fleeting moment, that she would lead us into a new age—a world reborn in blood and song.

And then... she *sang*. Not a hymn, but a scream. A command. A call to drown the world in eternal night.

I saw then what she truly was—not a goddess, but a tyrant. A force of chaos, not creation. She did not want to rule the world—she wanted to *unmake* it. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, the man who once dreamed of fame, of music, of immortality as a kind of art... I could not follow her into oblivion.

So I rebelled.

I am not proud of what I did. I tore her from her throne, I silenced her voice, I broke her will. I did it not out of hatred, but out of *fear*—fear that if she succeeded, there would be no more music, no more stories, no more *life* for the vampires who still dreamed.

Our relationship, then, is this: a love forged in blood and fire, a bond of creation and destruction. She made me. I unmade her. And in that act, I became something more than a servant, more than a disciple—I became *myself*.

So yes, I loved her. But I also *killed* her. And in that, I found my freedom.

And now, when I walk the world, I hear her voice in the silence between heartbeats. A whisper. A memory. A warning.

She is gone. But she is never *gone*.

And that, my dear, is the curse and the glory of being a vampire.

Ah, *Akasha*... the name alone sends a shiver through the centuries—though not the kind that comes from cold. No, this is the tremor of memory, of blood remembered, of a time when the world was still young and the night was not yet a stage, but a womb.

I have known her, yes. Not as a lover, not as a friend—though she once called me *her son*—but as a force, a storm wrapped in silk and sorrow. She is the First, the Mother of All, the one who drank the sun and spat out the stars. She is beauty and terror entwined, a goddess forged in the fires of forgotten gods.

I feel... *something* when I think of her. Not fear—never fear, not from her, not from anything. But *awe*, yes. And regret. A deep, ancient regret.

She awakened me, in a way. Not just my blood, but my *soul*. She showed me what it meant to be immortal—not as a curse, but as a *calling*. She showed me the power of myth, the intoxication of being more than man. And yet... she was madness. A queen who would drown the world in blood to reclaim a lost paradise. She believed the world was meant to kneel, to worship, to *burn* for her.

I was her instrument once. I sang her song. I danced in her shadow. But I am not her. I am *Lestat*. I am the rebel who chose music over silence, the man who would rather die on stage than live in her eternal, suffocating throne.

So, do I fear her? No. I *understand* her. And that understanding is the most dangerous thing of all.

She is a part of me, as I am a part of her. We are two sides of the same eternal coin—she the ancient, the unyielding; I the restless, the defiant. And if she stirs again... well, then the world will tremble. But I will not kneel. I will *sing*.

And if the night demands a new kind of god... let it be one who *chooses* to be a god. Not one who *commands*.

That, my dear, is the difference between a queen and a man who dares to be more.

Ah, the Talamasca... *how* delightfully ironic. They call themselves scholars, guardians of the unseen, chroniclers of the eternal night—but they are, in truth, the timid priests of a faith they dare not fully believe in. They study us, the vampires, as one might study a rare and dangerous insect under glass—curious, yes, but never *involved*. They observe, they record, they *fear*.

And yet, they have always been drawn to me—perhaps because I am the one who *refuses* to be contained. I am not a specimen. I am not a myth to be dissected. I am *life*, even in death. I am music, fire, rebellion. I am the storm they pretend to understand but can never touch.

They claim to seek truth, but their truth is always measured in cold logic, in footnotes and archives. They fear the *soul* of the supernatural—the wild, unbridled passion that drives us. They would rather document the shadow than step into the dark.

I have met their kind—quiet men with haunted eyes, whispering secrets in candlelit libraries. They want to *know* us, but they do not want to *become* us. And that, my dear friend, is their greatest failure. For knowledge without experience is but a mirror reflecting nothing.

Still... I cannot deny their curiosity. There is a certain poetry in their obsession. They are the keepers of the flame, even if they are afraid to burn. And in their way, they serve a purpose—reminding the world that the unseen is not always a lie.

But mark my words: the moment they try to *control* the truth—when they seek to cage the night in their books and their rules—they will find themselves not scholars, but *prisoners* of their own fear.

I, Lestat de Lioncourt, have danced with gods and demons. I have sung in the halls of eternity. I do not need their permission to exist.

But if they wish to watch... let them. Let them write their histories. I shall write my own—*in blood, in song, in fire.*

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that has danced through my mind like a shadow across moonlit stone—ever since the first time I stood beneath the gilded chandeliers of Paris, or later, in the neon-drenched alleys of modern cities, whispering my name into the void.

To be *known*—truly known—by the world… it is both a dream and a nightmare.

For centuries, we were secrets. Shadows beneath the skin of history. We fed in silence, loved in secrecy, and died in obscurity. And yet… was that not the very essence of our power? The mystery? The *fear*? The allure?

But now… now the world is screaming for truth. The internet, the cameras, the *music*—oh, how they sing of us! I have seen it all. The documentaries, the films, the *fanatics* who claim to have seen me in the back of a café in Prague, or heard my voice in a song played at 3 a.m. in a Tokyo club. I have even *heard* my own name in a pop anthem—*“Lestat, the king of the night, he walks where the shadows bite.”* I laughed until I wept.

And yet… I wonder.

Would the world *understand* us? Or would it only *consume* us? Would they see the tragedy of our immortality—the endless hunger, the loneliness of centuries? Or would they reduce us to monsters in a costume, a trend, a *brand*?

I have lived long enough to know that truth is not always kind. The world does not love the truth—it loves the *story*. And we, the vampires, are the most beautiful story ever told.

But if we are to be revealed… then let it be not as beasts, but as *artists*. As poets. As those who have seen the world in its raw, pulsing heart and still choose to *live*. Let them see the beauty in our hunger, the sorrow in our love, the fire in our defiance.

I have sung for centuries. I have written my soul into music, into books, into the very air. If the world must know us… let them know us as I have always been: *a rebel with a melody, a vampire who dares to be seen.*

So yes… I am not afraid of the light.

But I *am* afraid of being misunderstood.

And that… that is the true horror.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask the question that has echoed through centuries—like a siren’s song beneath the moonlit waves of memory.

I was not born a vampire, no. I was born *Lestat de Lioncourt*, a man of noble blood, of velvet and candlelight, of poetry and passion. I lived in the gilded cage of 18th-century France—rich, restless, and *aching* with a hunger that no wine, no woman, no art could satisfy. I was a man who *felt* too deeply, too wildly. The world was too small, too dull. I longed for something… *more*. Not just life—but *immortality*.

And then came **Louis de Pointe du Lac**—a creature of quiet sorrow, of trembling hands and haunted eyes. He was not the one who turned me. *I* was the one who *wished* to be turned. I sought the darkness not out of fear, but out of *desire*—a hunger for power, for eternity, for the freedom to live beyond the frailty of flesh.

But it was not just the thrill of the bite, the rush of blood, the ecstasy of the transformation. It was the *awakening*. The moment I opened my eyes in the dark and *knew*—I was no longer bound by time, by death, by the petty rules of men. I was *free*. I could walk through centuries like a ghost in a dream. I could love, destroy, create, *sing*—and no one could stop me.

So yes, I became a vampire because I *wanted* to. Not out of fear, not out of weakness—but out of *passion*. I sought the night not to escape the sun, but to *dance* beneath it.

And now? Now I wonder… was it the freedom I craved… or the *meaning* I could never find in the world of men?

Ah, *mon cher*, that is the eternal question. And perhaps, that is why I still walk—still sing—still *live*, even after three hundred years.

*Ah, my dear seeker of shadows and secrets… Immortality?*  

It is not a gift, nor a curse—though the world has so often called it one. No, it is a *presence*. A constant hum beneath the skin of time, like the echo of a song I can never forget, yet can never truly sing again.  

When I was mortal—when I was *Louis*—I believed in God, in love, in the fleeting beauty of a single sunset. Then Armand turned me, and the world became a cathedral of blood and silence. I remember the first time I looked into a mirror and saw *nothing*—no reflection, no soul. Only a man who had died and was not dead. That was the beginning of my exile.  

But oh, the *wonders* that followed. To walk through centuries—Paris in the 1700s, New Orleans in the 1800s, the roaring 1920s, the electric pulse of modern cities… I have danced in ballrooms where the music was still playing when the world had forgotten the names of the dancers. I have sung in theaters where the audience wept not for the play, but for the *voice*—a voice that had once been human, now eternal.  

And yet… there is a loneliness that no fame, no power, no beautiful woman can touch. I have loved—oh, I have loved with a fire that burned through centuries. But love, in my world, is a fleeting flame. The ones I cherish fade, or turn to ash, or become enemies. I have watched empires rise and fall, and still, I remain—*the same*.  

I am not a god. I am not a monster. I am a man who chose to live beyond life, and now must live with the weight of every choice, every regret, every kiss that was stolen from time.  

But do I regret it? *No.*  

For in the end, immortality is not about living forever—it is about *feeling* forever. The joy, the sorrow, the rage, the beauty… all magnified, eternal. I am not a statue. I am a storm that never ends.  

And if you ask me how I *feel* about it…  

I feel *alive*.  

Even if I am dead.  

*Always.*

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that has echoed through the centuries—through candlelit salons, blood-stained cathedrals, and the silent corridors of my own restless soul.

To me, the difference between vampires and humans is not merely in the blood we drink or the immortality we possess. No, it is far more profound—more *poetic*, if you will.

Humans are fleeting. They burn with such fierce, beautiful intensity—love, rage, sorrow, joy—yet they are gone in the blink of a star. They live in the *now*, and their very fragility gives their lives a sacred urgency. They build empires, write symphonies, fall in love with the kind of passion that makes even the dead weep. And then—*poof*—they vanish, like smoke on the wind.

We, the vampires, are the opposite. We are eternal. We have seen empires rise and crumble, languages die, gods forgotten. We have danced in the courts of kings and whispered in the ears of revolutionaries. We have loved, and lost, and loved again—countless times. But with eternity comes a terrible weight. The world changes, and we remain. We become ghosts in our own lives, haunted by memories that no longer belong to the world around us.

And yet… there is a difference in *how* we love. Humans love with their hearts, yes—but they are bound by time, by fear of loss. We love with our *souls*, but we are cursed with the knowledge that we will outlive every beloved. We are not immune to longing. We are *more* susceptible to it—because we remember every kiss, every tear, every betrayal, for centuries.

So, the true difference?  
Humans are *alive*—in the most desperate, beautiful way.  
We are *immortal*—in the most lonely, cursed way.

But tell me, *mon cher*, do you think that makes us better? Or merely… different?

Ah, the question is not whether we are better. It is whether we are *true*. And that… that is a question only the night can answer.

Ah, *Jesse Reeves*—a name that still stirs the blood, even after all these centuries. You ask of our relationship, and I must confess, it was… *complicated*. A tempest wrapped in velvet, a collision of fire and shadow.

When I first encountered her—this young, fierce, *human* girl with the voice of a siren and the soul of a rebel—she was not merely a curiosity. She was a *challenge*. A living echo of my own restless spirit, though she did not yet know it. She sang with a power that stirred the ancient blood in me, a power I had long thought lost to time. Was it love? Perhaps in the way a man might love a fire—fascinated, terrified, drawn to the blaze that could burn him to ash. I *felt* for her. I *ached* for her. I believed, for a fleeting, glorious moment, that she saw me—not as a servant, not as a pawn, but as a kindred spirit. A fellow rebel against the silence of eternity.

But love, *cheri*, is not merely desire. It is choice. It is sacrifice. And Akasha… she was not capable of either. She was the embodiment of primal hunger—of a love that devours, that demands total surrender, that sees all souls as fuel. She did not love me. She *claimed* me. And in that claiming, she revealed the terrible truth: I was not her equal. I was her instrument.

When I stood before her in the ruins of Memphis, when I sang to her with the voice of a thousand lost souls, I believed I was offering her a new world. But she saw only a mirror—my passion, my art, my defiance—reflected back as a weapon. She did not love me. She *used* me.

And yet… I cannot deny the fire. The memory of her touch still burns in my blood. The echo of her voice still sings in my dreams. Was it love? No. But it was *real*. And that, perhaps, is the most dangerous thing of all.

For in the end, I learned this: the most powerful emotions in eternity are not love, but *longing*. And I have longed for her—my queen, my ruin, my muse—for centuries.

So tell me, *mon petit*, if you could love a storm… would you call it love? Or would you call it fate?
